Subject: Re: [sfraves] Feed a family of four for $45 a week

Gardening fucking rocks!!

In the garden we grew last year I planted somewhere in the
nieghborhood of 6,000 poppy seeds, but I started WAY too late in the
season and not one damn one of them took.

grrrrh!!!!!

For those of you that have gmail the sunflower that I'm using as my
avatar pic is one that I grew ourselves, as well as these lovelies:
http://smg.photobucket.com/albums/v377/fabucat/Fruits%20And%20Vegetables/
http://tinyurl.com/lj949

here's a description of what we had growing between June and September:

So far, this year, we've got the following crops:

Cucumbers

Corn, Silver Dollar and Yellow

3-5 varieties of lettuce to include:

Arugula
Romaine
Endive
&
Mustard

Tomatoes to include:

Cherry
Roma
Beefsteak
&
Heirloom

Zucchini
Broccoli
Asparagus
Eggplant

Okra! Okra! Okra!

Peppers, Green and Purple

String Beans
Wax Beans
Italian Green Beans

Parsley
Sage
Rosemay
Thyme
Oregano
Basil, green and purple
Cilantro

Acorn Squash
Squash Squash
(see Misc Silly folder , Joel, you should really like this one, feel
free to pass it along to your friends on the internets.)

Pumpkins

Watermelon
Cantaloupe

Sunflowers, little ones and some fucking spectacular  12'-15 footers

and....

Catnip, because they're GOOD Cats!

Whew.

Until I actually sat down and wrote this above list out, I had no idea
that we had this much going on.

Wow.

This is really cool.

Of course, me being the Bizness Man that I am, there is a matter of
expense involved in all this.

The greatest being is the labor costs involved, but since we do that
on our time, we'll just write that one off.

Next is the water, especially this year since it's so dry, and
according to our bill for this summer, we're about $150-200 over
normal useage for a household our size.

Then comes the seeds, which at most was $50.

So the break-even point for this cornucopia of ours is between $200-$250usd.

That's pretty good, considering that it's a little over a month's
worth of groceries at the Safeway.

Added bonus, the time we're out in the garden is time that we're not
cruising Safeway's aisless getting visually assaulted by all that
Madison Avenue Product Packaging Come-ons that infest every shelf.

Anything that helps preserve my Mental Health Bandwidth and away from
flashy, eye-catching, logos that peddle toxins passing themselves off
as "food" is awesome.

Ya think?

Now, with a garden like this, there is a lot to keep track of.

For example, the Okra, Okra, Okra!!!

Jesus H. Christ on a shingle, does that shit grow fast.

If I ever get into Time Lapse Photography, they'll be an excellent
subject to do that sort of thing with.


Fucking awesome, kills me I'm NYC and in school so I'm not doing this this year.

nwa

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Feed a family of four for $45 a week

the great thing about papaver somniferum seeds is that you don't really  
need to plant them.  just go nuts and spread them around everywhere,  
and wait for the rain.

if you planted them too late, there's a good chance that about half of  
them will sprout next spring. once they get established, they spread  
like crazy.

-philip-




On Jun 6, 2006, at 5:51 PM, Joe Blough wrote:

> Gardening fucking rocks!!
>
> In the garden we grew last year I planted somewhere in the
> nieghborhood of 6,000 poppy seeds, but I started WAY too late in the
> season and not one damn one of them took.
>
> grrrrh!!!!!
>
> For those of you that have gmail the sunflower that I'm using as my
> avatar pic is one that I grew ourselves, as well as these lovelies:
> http://smg.photobucket.com/albums/v377/fabucat/ 
> Fruits%20And%20Vegetables/
> http://tinyurl.com/lj949
>
> here's a description of what we had growing between June and September:
>
> So far, this year, we've got the following crops:
>
> Cucumbers
>
> Corn, Silver Dollar and Yellow
>
> 3-5 varieties of lettuce to include:
>
> Arugula
> Romaine
> Endive
> &
> Mustard
>
> Tomatoes to include:
>
> Cherry
> Roma
> Beefsteak
> &
> Heirloom
>
> Zucchini
> Broccoli
> Asparagus
> Eggplant
>
> Okra! Okra! Okra!
>
> Peppers, Green and Purple
>
> String Beans
> Wax Beans
> Italian Green Beans
>
> Parsley
> Sage
> Rosemay
> Thyme
> Oregano
> Basil, green and purple
> Cilantro
>
> Acorn Squash
> Squash Squash
> (see Misc Silly folder , Joel, you should really like this one, feel
> free to pass it along to your friends on the internets.)
>
> Pumpkins
>
> Watermelon
> Cantaloupe
>
> Sunflowers, little ones and some fucking spectacular  12'-15 footers
>
> and....
>
> Catnip, because they're GOOD Cats!
>
> Whew.
>
> Until I actually sat down and wrote this above list out, I had no idea
> that we had this much going on.
>
> Wow.
>
> This is really cool.
>
> Of course, me being the Bizness Man that I am, there is a matter of
> expense involved in all this.
>
> The greatest being is the labor costs involved, but since we do that
> on our time, we'll just write that one off.
>
> Next is the water, especially this year since it's so dry, and
> according to our bill for this summer, we're about $150-200 over
> normal useage for a household our size.
>
> Then comes the seeds, which at most was $50.
>
> So the break-even point for this cornucopia of ours is between  
> $200-$250usd.
>
> That's pretty good, considering that it's a little over a month's
> worth of groceries at the Safeway.
>
> Added bonus, the time we're out in the garden is time that we're not
> cruising Safeway's aisless getting visually assaulted by all that
> Madison Avenue Product Packaging Come-ons that infest every shelf.
>
> Anything that helps preserve my Mental Health Bandwidth and away from
> flashy, eye-catching, logos that peddle toxins passing themselves off
> as "food" is awesome.
>
> Ya think?
>
> Now, with a garden like this, there is a lot to keep track of.
>
> For example, the Okra, Okra, Okra!!!
>
> Jesus H. Christ on a shingle, does that shit grow fast.
>
> If I ever get into Time Lapse Photography, they'll be an excellent
> subject to do that sort of thing with.
>
>
> Fucking awesome, kills me I'm NYC and in school so I'm not doing this  
> this year.
>
> nwa
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Hyperreal Donations Time!

If hyperreal isn't a 501(c) corp. it should become one.  There are many advantages including the ability to apply for grants from foundations and <gasp> the government.  It also avoids bad tax consequences for individuals that accept "donations" only to find out later that the IRS think these are "personal income".
 
 I've started two 510(c)3 corps FWIW...
 
 Regards,
 
 Peter

Hey all,

Just wanted to let you know that tomorrow we've got
Space Cowboy extraordinaire Ernie Trevino joining us
at Broke-Ass Thursdays tomorrow. Ernie is seriously
one of the most talented DJs I know, and I'm sure he's
gonna kill it with his slammin' tracks and
butter-smooth mixes - we really hope you can come
witness this turntable badass in action with us.

Ask the bartenders for this week's drink specials, or
check the specials board. Usually, it's an imported
beer for $3, and a shot special.

Broke-Ass Thursdays are always free, the first beat
drops at 9pm, and we go 'til 2am. @lpha bar is located
at 3848 Geary, at the corner of 3rd Ave. We hope to
see you there! 

-Evan

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

6/9 (Friday): Evil Breaks and dROW renegade beach
party with EB & dROW DJs + Evinrude. Check
www.evilbreaks.com for sign-up... or hit me up... I'll
give location info to the first five people to contact
me... shhhhh!

6/22 (Thursday): Broke-Ass Thursdays with Erik Hz +
another guest TBA.

6/23 (Friday): Space Cowboys' Unimog benefit at
Mighty. (What's up with the 'mog? See below...)

6/30 (Friday): Smoke Breaks with Donna Matrix
(NewsBreakz),
Dragn'fly (DJ4NORML/djdragnfly.com), Evinrude, Dirt,
Nugz. Stoked to have two of the finest female (I'm
talking skills, here... get your head out of the
gutter!) beatslingers in the Bay joining us for
installment # 6!

7/7 (Friday): Space Cowboys' Unimog benefit at Mighty
with Myagi, Simply Jeff & Ripe Superfriends.

7/13 (Thursday): Aaron Jae & Evinrude join Mycho Cocoa
& the Fringe at Nickie's.

7/22 (Saturday): Smoke Breaks with Mancub & Ernie
Trevino.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Want to see the Unimog on the playa this year? Want to
be a part of making the amazing new Version 2.0 a
reality? We need your help! She needs a lot of work,
parts, and equipment to make it happen, and
unfortunately that all costs money... You can help by
donating at www.spacecowboys.org - thank you!
--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_26058_1149702769_0--

> > one of the most talented DJs I know, and I'm sure he's 
> > gonna kill it with his slammin' tracks and 
> > butter-smooth mixes - we really hope you can come 
> > witness this turntable badass in action with us.

> > beer for $3, and a shot special.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Hyperreal Donations Time!

A few answers (best I can do):

Hyperreal is not a 501(c). Not exactly sure why, but given Brian's vast 
experience with corportions, incl. 501(c), and LLC's, I'm sure there's a 
reason.

Donations are *not* tax-deductible.

I'm not sure exactly what the upgrades are, aside from a new 2u box.

from Brian:
"Since 2003 or so, Hyperreal has been a dual-PIII 1.2Mhz box with 2GB of 
RAM and 160GB of RAID-ed hard disk space running
FreeBSD 4. About every 3 years I buy a new box, whatever is the latest and 
greatest that can run in a 2U rack mount space, and
I'm making plans to buy just such a new beastie."

I can find out specfics for the gearheads on this list.

Lastly, as mentioned in the original posting, PayPal donations to:

vvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvv

steph@hyperreal.org
(Steph Stiavetti)

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

hope this helps,

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

> A few answers (best I can do):
>
> Hyperreal is not a 501(c). Not exactly sure why, but given Brian's vast
> experience with corportions, incl. 501(c), and LLC's, I'm sure there's a
> reason.
>
> Donations are *not* tax-deductible.
>
> I'm not sure exactly what the upgrades are, aside from a new 2u box.
>
> from Brian:
> "Since 2003 or so, Hyperreal has been a dual-PIII 1.2Mhz box with 2GB of
> RAM and 160GB of RAID-ed hard disk space running
> FreeBSD 4. About every 3 years I buy a new box, whatever is the latest and
> greatest that can run in a 2U rack mount space, and
> I'm making plans to buy just such a new beastie."
>
> I can find out specfics for the gearheads on this list.

-- 
1. Creativity and innovation always builds on the past.
2. The past always tries to control the creativity that builds on it.
3. Free societies enable the future by living in the past.
4. Ours is a less and less a free society.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] TOMORROW!!!! 6/09/06: IGNITION @ BOCA w/ Myagi (Splank!/Money Shot Recordings - Canada) : Free before 10pm!!

That's right y'all - it's almost upon us - I'm gonna go pick up Myagi at 
7pm - he's stoked as shit about the party and so are all us DJ/promoter 
folk.

Remember - EVERYONE is on the guestlist until 10pm - after that it's only 
FIVE BUCKS to get your funk on!!!

Early buzz says this thing might go to capacity quick...so GET YER ASS DOWN 
TO BOCA EARLY!!!!

Details:


StrategiK (in cooperation w/ Urban Breaks & The Midnightsons) Presents:

IGNITION
Friday June 9th 2006
9pm to 2am

@ Boca (Bar of Contemporary Art)
414 Jessie Street, San Francisco

21 +
Free Before 10pm!
Just $5.00 After!!!

with your vinyl mechanics:

Jay Vigor - StrategiK / www.jayvigor.com (SF)
Undecided - Urban Breaks/ MOB Records (Sacramento)
Influence - StrategiK / www.nfluence.net (SF)
Marc(O) - Otherworld / www.TheMidnightsons.com / Ill Behavior (DC/SF)
Ill-D The DJ - Modified Productions / www.illdthedj.com (SF)
Evolution CQ - StrategiK / www.TheMidnightsons.com (SF)
Karlo - www.TheMidnightsons.com (SF/Seattle)
Audio MacGuyver - SolidGrooves (SJ)

and your very special guest pilot for the evening:

MYAGI (aka Sole Claw)  w/ MC Uprock - Money Shot Recordings / Splank! / 
Funky Cactus (Toronto, Canada)
www.myagimusic.com

"Myagi aka Sole Claw aka Andrew Mavor has shot up like a rocket over the 
last year. Representing Canada internationally, he has played from Seoul to 
San Francisco, Halifax to Brighton, Taipei to Toronto, and has become touted 
as the next major North American breaks don. Comparisons to the other big 
names of the scene seem obvious, but don't really do justice to the range of 
work Myagi has put out, as his releases have varied from hip hop big beat 
infused party breaks through to jackin house and techy big room floor 
fillers.

Dropping a guitar in favor of a synthesizer well before finishing high 
school, Mavor's musical journey has landed him across the board support. The 
late John Peel (the Peel Sessions) used a Myagi track to open his show. 
Front 242 have sent kudos on a track ("Sole Claw - Smartbomb") that was 
licensed to Fingerlickin for the Plump DJ's album "Saturday Night Lotion."

The string of red hot releases that followed have landed him sets on the 
BBC, the CBC and Crystal Method's Community Service and support from 
everyone from Adam Freeland and Meat Katie through to Fatboy Slim and Freddy 
Fresh. Myagi's multi-genre approach to dance music has matured into a true 
journey through b-boy and rave culture, mashing up past and present in one 
of the most high energy, pounding experiences a club could play host to. His 
shows at clubs like The Guvernment in Toronto have led to high profile gigs 
internationally, including such highlights as Fabric in London, Fusion in 
Taiwan and San Francisco's Love Parade, where Myagi played three parties in 
12 hours.

His upcoming releases include remixes for Ursula 1000 (coming out on 
Thievery Corporations label ESL), hip hop don Maestro (as in Fresh Wes), and 
a giant remix for Ricky Stone. He has two tracks licensed to JDS's "Beats N 
Bobs" compilation on Functional Breaks, more remixes in the works, and a 
release schedule that puts most labels to shame. Touring constantly, Myagi 
is one of the hardest working men in the North American dance music, and, 
with his profile rising at an extremely rapid pace he has quickly turned 
himself into a staple of the global breaks scene. "

Forget everything you thought you knew about breaks in San Francisco...you 
ears are about to be flipped!!!

FREE before 10pm!!!!


~Marc(O)
Otherworld // Midnightsons // Ill Behavior // Mario Bros (SF/DC)

Subject: [sfraves] Save PBS & NPR

------=_NextPart_000_0049_01C68B27.87690530
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi,

Everyone expected House Republicans to give up efforts to kill NPR and =
PBS after a massive public outcry stopped them last year. But they've =
just voted to eliminate funding for NPR and PBSunbelievably, starting =
with programs like "Sesame Street."

Public broadcasting would lose nearly a quarter of its federal funding =
this year. Even worse, all funding would be eliminated in two =
years--threatening one of the last remaining sources of watchdog =
journalism.

Sign the petition telling Congress to save NPR and PBS again this year:

http://civic.moveon.org/publicbroadcasting/


Last year, millions of us took action to save NPR and PBS, and Congress =
listened. We can do it again if enough of us sign the petition in time.

This would be the most severe cut in the history of public broadcasting. =
The Boston Globe reports the cuts "could force the elimination of some =
popular PBS and NPR programs." NPR's president expects rural public =
radio stations may be forced to shut down.

The House and Senate are deciding if public broadcasting will survive, =
and they need to hear from viewers like you. Sign the petition at:

http://civic.moveon.org/publicbroadcasting/

Thanks!

P.S. Read the Boston Globe story on the threat to NPR and PBS at:

http://www.moveon.org/r?r=3D1864


Paul 
------=_NextPart_000_0049_01C68B27.87690530--

On Jun 8, 2006, at 4:28 PM, Marc((O)) wrote:

> That's right y'all - it's almost upon us - I'm gonna go pick up  
> Myagi at 7pm - he's stoked as shit about the party and so are all  
> us DJ/promoter folk.
>
> Remember - EVERYONE is on the guestlist until 10pm - after that  
> it's only FIVE BUCKS to get your funk on!!!
>
> Early buzz says this thing might go to capacity quick...so GET YER  
> ASS DOWN TO BOCA EARLY!!!!
>
> Details:
>
>
> StrategiK (in cooperation w/ Urban Breaks & The Midnightsons)  
> Presents:
>
> IGNITION
> Friday June 9th 2006
> 9pm to 2am
>
> @ Boca (Bar of Contemporary Art)
> 414 Jessie Street, San Francisco
>
> 21 +
> Free Before 10pm!
> Just $5.00 After!!!
>
> with your vinyl mechanics:
>
> Jay Vigor - StrategiK / www.jayvigor.com (SF)
> Undecided - Urban Breaks/ MOB Records (Sacramento)
> Influence - StrategiK / www.nfluence.net (SF)
> Marc(O) - Otherworld / www.TheMidnightsons.com / Ill Behavior (DC/SF)
> Ill-D The DJ - Modified Productions / www.illdthedj.com (SF)
> Evolution CQ - StrategiK / www.TheMidnightsons.com (SF)
> Karlo - www.TheMidnightsons.com (SF/Seattle)
> Audio MacGuyver - SolidGrooves (SJ)
>
> and your very special guest pilot for the evening:
>
> MYAGI (aka Sole Claw)  w/ MC Uprock - Money Shot Recordings /  
> Splank! / Funky Cactus (Toronto, Canada)
> www.myagimusic.com
>
> "Myagi aka Sole Claw aka Andrew Mavor has shot up like a rocket  
> over the last year. Representing Canada internationally, he has  
> played from Seoul to San Francisco, Halifax to Brighton, Taipei to  
> Toronto, and has become touted as the next major North American  
> breaks don. Comparisons to the other big names of the scene seem  
> obvious, but don't really do justice to the range of work Myagi has  
> put out, as his releases have varied from hip hop big beat infused  
> party breaks through to jackin house and techy big room floor fillers.
>
> Dropping a guitar in favor of a synthesizer well before finishing  
> high school, Mavor's musical journey has landed him across the  
> board support. The late John Peel (the Peel Sessions) used a Myagi  
> track to open his show. Front 242 have sent kudos on a track ("Sole  
> Claw - Smartbomb") that was licensed to Fingerlickin for the Plump  
> DJ's album "Saturday Night Lotion."
>
> The string of red hot releases that followed have landed him sets  
> on the BBC, the CBC and Crystal Method's Community Service and  
> support from everyone from Adam Freeland and Meat Katie through to  
> Fatboy Slim and Freddy Fresh. Myagi's multi-genre approach to dance  
> music has matured into a true journey through b-boy and rave  
> culture, mashing up past and present in one of the most high  
> energy, pounding experiences a club could play host to. His shows  
> at clubs like The Guvernment in Toronto have led to high profile  
> gigs internationally, including such highlights as Fabric in  
> London, Fusion in Taiwan and San Francisco's Love Parade, where  
> Myagi played three parties in 12 hours.
>
> His upcoming releases include remixes for Ursula 1000 (coming out  
> on Thievery Corporations label ESL), hip hop don Maestro (as in  
> Fresh Wes), and a giant remix for Ricky Stone. He has two tracks  
> licensed to JDS's "Beats N Bobs" compilation on Functional Breaks,  
> more remixes in the works, and a release schedule that puts most  
> labels to shame. Touring constantly, Myagi is one of the hardest  
> working men in the North American dance music, and, with his  
> profile rising at an extremely rapid pace he has quickly turned  
> himself into a staple of the global breaks scene. "
>
> Forget everything you thought you knew about breaks in San  
> Francisco...you ears are about to be flipped!!!
>
> FREE before 10pm!!!!
>
>
> ~Marc(O)
> Otherworld // Midnightsons // Ill Behavior // Mario Bros (SF/DC)
>

CAUSTIC

&
DJing by Spin THIS! Residents

at the Balazo 18 Gallery
2183 Mission St, near the corner of 18th.

$8

performance!

now!  His first SF Performance!

full effect!  C/A/T's new EP 'ATF' is available now. 8 tracks in  
all... featuring the brand new tracks 'Smashed v2' and '[We Make]  
Music To Piss You Off' as well as remixes from Caustic and Terrorfakt!

The Operative- His debut album will be out this summer! "an adoring  
circle of radical calamity".  First SF performance!

>> StrategiK (in cooperation w/ Urban Breaks & The Midnightsons)  Presents:
>>
>> IGNITION
>> Friday June 9th 2006
>> 9pm to 2am
>>
>> @ Boca (Bar of Contemporary Art)
>> 414 Jessie Street, San Francisco
>>
>> 21 +
>> Free Before 10pm!
>> Just $5.00 After!!!
>>
>> with your vinyl mechanics:
>>
>> Jay Vigor - StrategiK / www.jayvigor.com (SF)
>> Undecided - Urban Breaks/ MOB Records (Sacramento)
>> Influence - StrategiK / www.nfluence.net (SF)
>> Marc(O) - Otherworld / www.TheMidnightsons.com / Ill Behavior (DC/SF)
>> Ill-D The DJ - Modified Productions / www.illdthedj.com (SF)
>> Evolution CQ - StrategiK / www.TheMidnightsons.com (SF)
>> Karlo - www.TheMidnightsons.com (SF/Seattle)
>> Audio MacGuyver - SolidGrooves (SJ)
>>
>> and your very special guest pilot for the evening:
>>
>> MYAGI (aka Sole Claw)  w/ MC Uprock - Money Shot Recordings /  Splank! / 
>> Funky Cactus (Toronto, Canada)
>> www.myagimusic.com
>>
>> "Myagi aka Sole Claw aka Andrew Mavor has shot up like a rocket  over the 
>> last year. Representing Canada internationally, he has  played from Seoul 
>> to San Francisco, Halifax to Brighton, Taipei to  Toronto, and has become 
>> touted as the next major North American  breaks don. Comparisons to the 
>> other big names of the scene seem  obvious, but don't really do justice 
>> to the range of work Myagi has  put out, as his releases have varied from 
>> hip hop big beat infused  party breaks through to jackin house and techy 
>> big room floor fillers.
>>
>> Dropping a guitar in favor of a synthesizer well before finishing  high 
>> school, Mavor's musical journey has landed him across the  board support. 
>> The late John Peel (the Peel Sessions) used a Myagi  track to open his 
>> show. Front 242 have sent kudos on a track ("Sole  Claw - Smartbomb") 
>> that was licensed to Fingerlickin for the Plump  DJ's album "Saturday 
>> Night Lotion."
>>
>> The string of red hot releases that followed have landed him sets  on the 
>> BBC, the CBC and Crystal Method's Community Service and  support from 
>> everyone from Adam Freeland and Meat Katie through to  Fatboy Slim and 
>> Freddy Fresh. Myagi's multi-genre approach to dance  music has matured 
>> into a true journey through b-boy and rave  culture, mashing up past and 
>> present in one of the most high  energy, pounding experiences a club 
>> could play host to. His shows  at clubs like The Guvernment in Toronto 
>> have led to high profile  gigs internationally, including such highlights 
>> as Fabric in  London, Fusion in Taiwan and San Francisco's Love Parade, 
>> where  Myagi played three parties in 12 hours.
>>
>> His upcoming releases include remixes for Ursula 1000 (coming out  on 
>> Thievery Corporations label ESL), hip hop don Maestro (as in  Fresh Wes), 
>> and a giant remix for Ricky Stone. He has two tracks  licensed to JDS's 
>> "Beats N Bobs" compilation on Functional Breaks,  more remixes in the 
>> works, and a release schedule that puts most  labels to shame. Touring 
>> constantly, Myagi is one of the hardest  working men in the North 
>> American dance music, and, with his  profile rising at an extremely rapid 
>> pace he has quickly turned  himself into a staple of the global breaks 
>> scene. "
>>
>> Forget everything you thought you knew about breaks in San 
>> Francisco...you ears are about to be flipped!!!
>>
>> FREE before 10pm!!!!
>>
>>
>> ~Marc(O)
>> Otherworld // Midnightsons // Ill Behavior // Mario Bros (SF/DC)
>>

ALUMNI

from 1996 and earlier.

$10. $5 < 11pm;
$5 with raverwear.

Robbie Hardkiss (SFRaves / Deep Faith / Fields of Joy)
Jenö (Wicked / Toontown / Gathering)
Dutch (Area 51 / CDC Soundsystem / Chemistry)
Carlos (Area 51 / CDC Soundsystem / SF House)

Lounge:
Tracy (Ameba / Endup / Area 51)
Ethan (Friends and Family / Vision / Mad Mondays)
Galen (Sunset / Pacific Sound / Freedom)
Solar (Sunset / Pacific Sound / Abstract Soul)

Old School Visuals by Dax.
Retro Raver Wear encouraged!
-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

May 12th:  Under Construction @ Suede
May 13th:  So You Want Some Breaks? @ Butter
May 20th:  DIRTY w/ Circuitbreaker @ Jelly's

In fact you should assume that every bit sent on the Internet is comprimised at this point.  Don't openly publish stuff on the Internet that you don't want to make public.  Especially someplace like MySpace which is owned by Rupert Murdoch now.  Read the fine print in their user agreement and see what rights they claim to your publications.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1984 was only 20 years in coming

-------------------------------1149876088
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Also, note that in Myspace (and other site) profiles can be searched by  
name. So, you might have a job interview and they type in your name and find  that 
you go to parties every weekend or whatever. 
A couple ways around this: 
When you first got onto myspace, you might have typed in your real name,  but 
there is actually no need to do this. Go in and change your name. I just  
left in the first letter of my last name. Then, nobody can search for the  
profile by name. 
Another way is to say in your profile that you're under 15 years old. Then,  
only your friends can see your profile. 
Some friend was warning me that companies are typing names into myspace to  
see what comes up, and then I read something about it in the newspaper.  
Companies are not allowed to ASK a lot of things in an interview, but if you  post 
information yourself and they happen to find it, it's fair game, and you  might 
not get that job. 
 
Another way: put in your pr

-------------------------------1149876088--

Yes - any job can use your social networking sites against you folks, so BE 
STEALTHY!
----- Original Message ----- 
From: <JonnyR@aol.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, June 09, 2006 11:01 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1984 was only 20 years in coming


> Also, note that in Myspace (and other site) profiles can be searched by
> name. So, you might have a job interview and they type in your name and 
> find  that
> you go to parties every weekend or whatever.
> A couple ways around this:
> When you first got onto myspace, you might have typed in your real name, 
> but
> there is actually no need to do this. Go in and change your name. I just
> left in the first letter of my last name. Then, nobody can search for the
> profile by name.
> Another way is to say in your profile that you're under 15 years old. 
> Then,
> only your friends can see your profile.
> Some friend was warning me that companies are typing names into myspace to
> see what comes up, and then I read something about it in the newspaper.
> Companies are not allowed to ASK a lot of things in an interview, but if 
> you  post
> information yourself and they happen to find it, it's fair game, and you 
> might
> not get that job.
>
> Another way: put in your pr
>

Actually there's currently a big fuss over this exact issue:

http://publishing2.com/2006/06/07/billy-bragg-walks-away-from-myspace/

And myspace's response:

Myspace.com spokesman Jeff Berman says, 'Because the legalese has caused some confusion, we are at work revising it to make it very clear that MySpace is not seeking a license to
do anything with an artist's work other than allow it to be shared in the manner the artist intends. Obviously, we don't own their music or do anything with it that they don't want.'

> > and PBS after a massive public outcry stopped them last year. But
> > they've just voted to eliminate funding for NPR and
> > PBSunbelievably, starting with programs like "Sesame Street."
> >
> > Public broadcasting would lose nearly a quarter of its federal
> > funding this year. Even worse, all funding would be eliminated in
> > two years--threatening one of the last remaining sources of
> > watchdog journalism.
> >
> > Sign the petition telling Congress to save NPR and PBS again this
> > year:
> >
> > http://civic.moveon.org/publicbroadcasting/
> >
> >
> > Last year, millions of us took action to save NPR and PBS, and
> > Congress listened. We can do it again if enough of us sign the
> > petition in time.
> >
> > This would be the most severe cut in the history of public
> > broadcasting. The Boston Globe reports the cuts "could force the
> > elimination of some popular PBS and NPR programs." NPR's president
> > expects rural public radio stations may be forced to shut down.
> >
> > The House and Senate are deciding if public broadcasting will
> > survive, and they need to hear from viewers like you. Sign the
> > petition at:
> >
> > http://civic.moveon.org/publicbroadcasting/
> >
> > Thanks!
> >
> > P.S. Read the Boston Globe story on the threat to NPR and PBS at:
> >
> > http://www.moveon.org/r?r=1864
> >
> >

-- 
1. Creativity and innovation always builds on the past.
2. The past always tries to control the creativity that builds on it.
3. Free societies enable the future by living in the past.
4. Ours is a less and less a free society.

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Save PBS & NPR

Fresh Air is hands down one of the best interview shows out there. I 
have heard everything from politicians sweating bullets from some of the 
difficult questions presented to spongebob being goofy. This American 
Life is a touching and powerful portrayal of everyday people and the 
ways they negotiate the world. Marketplace takes more of a worldly, 
democratic approach to money and finance, as opposed to the usual 
sources that takes it from the spin that greed comes before all else.

Spark on PBS is a bay area artist series that presents in depth 
documentary video on painters, filmmakers, sculptures, fire artist, 
eclectics, and galleries. You think local news presents in depth clips 
about the local arts? Not any that I've seen.

 I don't believe there is a wider breadth of programming in existence 
than whats on NPR and PBS. In america, at least.

-t

------=_Part_32834_4296445.1149884855919
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

I happen to adore NPR. I love Car Talk. Not because I have any real interes=
t
in cars or how to fix them, but just because its an awesome show. I agree
that Fresh Air is killer, and This American Life is the most amazing show
I've ever listened to. In addition, I absolutely love Prairie Home
Companion. There is nothing out there that can even compare to it.

PBS puts out Frontline, which is the last honest and educated documentaries
out there. I also have a soft spot for Nova (the nature and science show).

The fact that there are no advertisements is what initially drew me in. The=
y
are also what keeps me there. I'd rather not have my brain spammed with
Cheeto's and Count Chocula. My boyfriend and I make regular donations, and
we are just regular people with regular jobs.

I make fun of myself sometimes because I used to think my dad was such a
dork for listening to that stuff. But at the old age of 23, I am already in
love with it.

The only people that say they "hate" NPR and PBS are the ones that haven't
watched it. People (especially Americans) tend to "hate" things that they
don't understand or refuse to learn about.

Tala

Etymology: Sanskrit tAla, literally, hand-clapping
: one of the ancient traditional rhythmic patterns of Indian music --
compare RAGA

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 2006 15:39:40 -0700 (PDT)
From: rayn@anubismedia.net
To: "Tala ..." <technotala@gmail.com>
Cc: "John Dee" <antitux@gmail.com>, "SFR" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.2
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Save PBS & NPR

The problem with 'selling out' to advertising revenue is that advertisers
can start pushing their agenda's on you once they know you depend on their
money.  From there they can sway and put pressure on people to play or not
play certain kinds of content with the threat of pulling advertising from
it.  Typically when this is threatened, its not just one sponsor but an ad
agency's pipeline of advertising that gets pulled.  This is why
listener/watcher sponsored media is so important.  Say PBS starts working
with an ad agency who handles something like chevy or ford.. then PBS
decides to have some indepth reporting about Microsoft and antitrust cases
but the ad agency also handles Microsoft.  Microsoft could (and would) put
pressure on the ad agency to either pull their contract with PBS or force
PBS to not air or change an episode.

.02

-Rayn

> I happen to adore NPR. I love Car Talk. Not because I have any real
> interest
> in cars or how to fix them, but just because its an awesome show. I agree
> that Fresh Air is killer, and This American Life is the most amazing show
> I've ever listened to. In addition, I absolutely love Prairie Home
> Companion. There is nothing out there that can even compare to it.
>
> PBS puts out Frontline, which is the last honest and educated
> documentaries
> out there. I also have a soft spot for Nova (the nature and science show).
>
> The fact that there are no advertisements is what initially drew me in.
> They
> are also what keeps me there. I'd rather not have my brain spammed with
> Cheeto's and Count Chocula. My boyfriend and I make regular donations, and
> we are just regular people with regular jobs.
>
> I make fun of myself sometimes because I used to think my dad was such a
> dork for listening to that stuff. But at the old age of 23, I am already
> in
> love with it.
>
> The only people that say they "hate" NPR and PBS are the ones that haven't
> watched it. People (especially Americans) tend to "hate" things that they
> don't understand or refuse to learn about.
>
> Tala
>

 Mighty 119 Utah St @ 15th.
 No downtempo in sight for this one, but a sure fire crazy party.

For those of you who got to check out Damian at our last Funkycozy, he played some phenomenal music that you're not likely to hear at your regular parties. We're really excited that he is back in town. We have an excellent lineup of Funkycozy and Kontrol residents to kick things off - so make sure you don't miss out and get yourselves a pre-sale ticket now!

> The problem with 'selling out' to advertising revenue is that advertisers
> can start pushing their agenda's on you once they know you depend on thei=
r
> money.  From there they can sway and put pressure on people to play or no=
t
> play certain kinds of content with the threat of pulling advertising from
> it.  Typically when this is threatened, its not just one sponsor but an a=
d
> agency's pipeline of advertising that gets pulled.  This is why
> listener/watcher sponsored media is so important.  Say PBS starts working
> with an ad agency who handles something like chevy or ford.. then PBS
> decides to have some indepth reporting about Microsoft and antitrust case=
s
> but the ad agency also handles Microsoft.  Microsoft could (and would) pu=

1. Creativity and innovation always builds on the past.
2. The past always tries to control the creativity that builds on it.
3. Free societies enable the future by living in the past.
4. Ours is a less and less a free society.

From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org] 
Sent: Monday, June 05, 2006 9:02 PM
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: GEMINI ARTS MUSIC AND DANCE GATHERING 2006

JUNE 9,10,11th 

BROUGHT TO YOU BY: FULL CIRCLE PRODUCTIONS, PHOENIX FAMILY and YOU to
Mapquest: 14785 Belden Town Rd., Belden, Ca. 95915  (530) 283-9662

http://geomagnetic.tv/events/gemini2006.html

http://forum.isratrance.com/viewtopic.php/topic/87596/forum/28/start/45
***********************************************************


Greetings and Namaste,

The time has come once again for the legendary and much anticipated northern
California underground outdoor music festival lovingly known as GEMINI. This
gathering is dedicated to unifying our bay area, USA, and international
global music family. Artists from all over the world and many nations have
committed to creating an intentional community located in our own private
town called Belden, 3.5hrs NE of San Francisco (full directions from all
areas below) . That's right, we are taking over a whole resort, complete
with bathrooms, showers and dance floor porta-potties.

This is a FREE gathering, (i.e. No Entrance or parking/camping Fee) which
means it is what we all make it. To support this gathering please LEAVE NO
TRACE and prepare to clean up after yourself and to urge your
neighbors/friends to do the same Please CARPOOL to save room for camping and
for the environment. =)

We are calling out to any and all participants who would like to help create
a sacred, mystical setting for us to experience true freedom and bliss. If
you have decorations, want to volunteer time, anything that you think would
make this gathering better or safer Please contact: Richard
(wichdokta@hotmail.com)

Please welcome all the new family members that are traveling from across the
world to present their music and artistic creations for us enjoy. The new
energy is going to be very welcome on the dance floor. 
This is going to be something a very unique and special gathering.

We proudly present 3 stages of different music for your listening pleasure.
a dance stage, chill area and we have a whole stage of live rock n roll,
jam, hip-hop, "techno" and reggae style bands during the day and early
evening to bring back that old GEMINI vibe. PLEASE
NOTE: Renegade sound systems will not be tolerated, you will be shut down
and kindly asked to leave the gathering. Spread the word to all family and
friends about this UNIQUE and SACRED gathering and the amazing new venue. So
get ready to have a great time and collectively transform this town into a
"PSYCHEDELIC CITY".

Belden Resort
14785 Belden Town Rd., Belden, Ca. 95915 (530) 283-9662 Surrounded by
majestic mountains, you will drive by many waterfalls and through rock
mountain tunnels, view luscious valleys of green and old bridges on your
journey into the Sierra foothills. The river that runs adjacent to the town
is great for rafting and swimming. The event location has plenty of camping
under the trees. There is an Old Style Saloon there for drinks, snax and
water. All cabins at Belden are now reserved. There are additional Rooms for
rent only 1.5 miles from the event at the beautiful Pine Air Hotel (530) 283
- 1730

Sound on both stages by: Full Circle featuring a giant system for the Dance
Stage with 30,000 watts of Pleasure!
Visuals on both stages by: Geomagnetic.tv Decorations and Sacred Shrines by:
Mindalters, Taodeco and the Phoenix Family LINE UP FOR DANCE STAGE

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------
** FROM THE BAY AREA **

Take hwy. 80 towards Sacramento. Take the Hwy. 505 off ramp and follow it to
I-5. Take the I-5 North to Williams. Once in Williams, take the Hwy.20 East.
( Follow the Hwy.20 signs when you come to the first town ). Once past the
first town you will follow Hwy.20 to Yuba City/Marysville. These 2 towns are
separated only by a bridge, you can't miss it. Once over the bridge and in
Marysville, be in the fast lane and follow the Hwy.70 signs. It's alittle
tricky but if you pay attention you will get through it. Follow Hwy.70 about
49 miles past Oroville and turn right into Belden Town. There are signs for
the town on the Hwy. "

** FROM NORTH OF S.F. ** (Anywhere north of Santa Rosa)

Take Hwy. 101 to Hwy.20 East 5 miles north of Ukiah. Follow Hwy.20 all the
way to Yuba City/Marysville. ( pay close attention to the Hwy.20 signs at
the first town past Williams). Once in Yuba City/Marysville you will go over
a bridge ( this bridge separates the towns, you can't miss it ) be in the
fast lane and follow the Hwy.70 signs. It's a little tricky so pay
attention. Follow Hwy.70 about 49 miles past Oroville to Belden Town. There
are signs on the Hwy. for this town. Take a right over the bridge and your
there.

** FROM LOS ANGELES **

Take the I-5 North to the Hwy.99 junction and take the Hwy.99 to Yuba City.
Take a right onto Hwy.20 towards Marysville. Be in the fast lane and follow
the Hwy.70 signs once over the Marysville Bridge. You can't miss it. Follow
the Hwy. 70 signs carefully, they're a little tricky. Follow Hwy.70 about 49
miles past Oroville to Belden Town. 
There are signs on the Hwy. for this Town. Take a right over the bridge and
your there.

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path toward
social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and enlightened people
come to us from all cultures and all eras, sometimes knowing of each other
but more often not.  Socrates and Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and
Martin Buber -- no one can find in their lives and words a jot of support
for a political and economic regime that encourages the acquisition of
wealth far beyond what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the
restorative pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and
work in squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Weekend Adventures

Favorite quote this weekend: "Don't blow up the spot - park accross the 
street"

Man was this weekend rediculous.. wtf is up with acid totem these days?? The 
beach spot was mad.. ripple was there with gamma who hooked me up with a 
ticket for stilldream (still don't know if I can go).. spun some fire with 
opulent temple at ocean, and got to hang out with some new girlfriends.. 
yeah for being single for the first time in seven years :)  Then Sat was THE 
ROOTS!!! with Blacklicious (hell ya) followed by NK7.  Man was it hot as 
hell in there.. nice touch with the fans though and the music was 
incredible.  That party was phat..  Isacc was working door and he is by far 
one of the coolest mofos on the planet, and I met this whole russian 
collective.. well thier girlfriends anyway.. but that smoking / chillroom 
was the bomb for quite a while.  Bounced, went to Detention, and proceeded 
to get very drunk in the hot tub.. and then got lost upstairs in a blanket 
fort :-) Yes.. home at 8:30am every day this weekend.. time to rest.

SFR: Ranger
San Francisco
plurranger@hotmail.com

It's dark and no one can see

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 2006 15:18:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
cc: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <7.0.1.0.2.20060606131902.045f9d88@speakeasy.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0606121441480.5350@atari>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RIP Billy Preston


Whaaa, just saw this.

Billy Preston was one of those people who could sing a song you didn't 
like so much and turn it into something amazing.  Same melody, new tune.

Check the George Harrison Memorial Concert DVD for an amazing instance of 
this ability, his solo and verse contribution to the cheeseball 
supergroup's performance of "Isn't it a Pity" are just godly (and leave 
Eric Clapton looking like a mumbling no talent hack).  Amazing voice, the 
kind of beaming presence that makes you just want to spend a day with him 
asking questions and just listening and the guy could play the shit out of 
a Hammond B3 Organ, Clavinet and Fender Rhodes like few have or ever will.  
A true gospel, blues and rock virtuoso without ever betraying himself or 
the songs he played (well, some of the 70s organ pop cover compilations 
are pretty bad, but even they found their way into sample heavy albums 
like "Check your Head" by the Beastie Boys [even though Mario Caldatto is 
a badass keyboard player himself and was present for those sessions]).  
His discography reads like a list of high points of the bands he worked 
with, some of the most lasting work of the 20th century.  He wrote "you 
are so beautiful" for joe cocker.  Played keys for Sam Cooke, Little 
Richard, Beatles and their later solo projects, Aretha Franklin, Jackson5, 
Sly Stone, Eric Clapton, Neil Diamond and Bob Dylan (in most cases on 
their strongest work).

much respect to a life well lived,
andyw

p.s.	extra kudos for putting out an album in 1965 entitled "most 
exciting organ ever".

p.p.s.	check out the "12 songs" release by Neil Diamond if you haven't... 
it's actually quite amazing (Rick Rubin produced, came out last year)

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Saturday, June 17

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 3rd Saturday at Rx Gallery

ONE YEAR ANNIVERSARY!


featuring from Detroit in a world premiere dual live PA:


RYAN CROSSON   ( m-nus . trapez . telegraph . archipel )

vs. LEE CURTISS    ( kalimari . iron box . rhumba muzik )


Detroit's latest wave hits as Ryan Crosson (aka Berg Nixon) and Lee Curtiss
join forces for the first time ever in a cooperative dual live PA.  Crosson=
,
hot off his amazing performance at the M-nus "min2MAX" DEMF afterparty (and
equally outstanding track on the new compilation of the same name), has bee=
n
blowing up worldwide in the last couple years. Curtiss, recently back from =
3
months stationed in Berlin and performing all over Europe, is one of the
minimal world's brightest rising young stars.  Individually, each of these
guys deliver a live PA of thumpy, dark, and crisp minimal techno that is
absolutely stunning.  Together=85we can only imagine.


plus resident DJs:

ALLAND BYALLO   ( liebe*detail . kvadrat produkt . mo's ferry )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
CRAIG KUNA   ( concept sf . esdjco )


Rx Gallery Art Exhibition: Frankenstein Theory and Robotics

________________________________________________

Rx Gallery
132 Eddy @ Mason, SF / 415.474.7973
9pm-2am / 21+ / $10
________________________________________________

Check our website for full bios, pics and lots FREE music!
http://www.kontrolsf.com

View the flyer here:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K13W.gif

View the poster here:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K13P.jpg

________________________________________________


BIOS:

RYAN CROSSON
Born and raised in Metro-Detroit, Ryan discovered electronic music in his
late teenage years. After strictly DJing for a few years, he took the next
logical step by beginning to produce his own music in Fall 2003.  Drawing
from artists like Plastikman, Matthew Dear, Stewart Walker, and a heavy dos=
e
of Magda DJ sets, Ryan focused his attention on percussive programming,
dubby basslines, and dark atmospheres.  By expressing a tireless work ethic
in the studio, Ryan was soon noticed for his efforts by local Detroit label=
,
Beretta Music.  Not long after this, Ryan signed music to Cologne based
label Trapez Limited, just one year after he began writing music.  The EP
release on Trapez LTD. titled, "Say So " was well received with many
positive reviews from a plethora of international artists. In the Summer of
2005, Ryan played his first international dates with impressive live
performances in Berlin, and Cologne.  He has recently taken on a production
alais, "Berg Nixon" under which he was honored with a track on the latest
M-nus compilation, "min2MAX", as well as scoring a pair of remixes for the
latest Troy Pierce 12", "25 Bitches". Current influences include Pierce,
Ricardo Villalobos, Matthew Dear, and Guido Schneider. Talented and driven,
this young Detroit native is making an impact internationally with his
music.   Look for upcoming releases and remixes in the coming months from
Ryan on Minus, Beretta Grey, Telegraph and Trapez Ltd.

LEE CURTISS
Lee has always found sanctuary in the corners of his mind, for in the
corners you will find your true nature and true creative being. His mission
is to free people from the confines of the music they are accustomed to
listening to and elevate electronic music to the next level. He found
himself fixated on music from an early age, constantly learning more about
music as he taught himself to play several instruments over time. When he
found the dance music scene, he immediately moved away from rock oriented
instruments and gravitated toward electronic music. He was completely
fascinated by the anonymity of artists, the raw power of the music and how
it made the crowd move with every churning rhythm until it seemed everyone
was ready to lose their minds all at once. After traveling to Detroit and
Chicago he realized that he had something to contribute to this music and
began collecting records and DJing in 2000. Two years later he had amassed
enough knowledge and equipment to commit to producing full force. He soon
relocated from Grand Rapids to Detroit where he broadened his musical scope
and continued sharpening his skills. His music has become a heavily German
influenced form of minimal with an unorthodox approach to textures and
rhythms, using lo fidelity to create elements of disarray surrounded by
crunching beats, tweaky synthlines, held together by bubble gum sticky bass
lines. With a recent 3 month tour of Europe behind him, a track on the new
Audion Fabric mix, and upcoming releases on Spectral Sound, Underl_ne, and
Milnor Modern, Lee Curtiss is an artist clearly on his way up and showing n=
o
signs of slowing down.

--0-787480367-1150163265=:89842
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

You know, I actually had a rather unexpectedly remarkable Friday night. Started at UndergroundSF to join my friends in visiting their oldest and dearest friend Jen from Maine  - http://www.popgirl23.com/. We were just about the only people there, and we danced our asses off all over the floor while she played some lovely house. Fun!
   
  Then, my friend Rocky was throwing his first ever underground in a warehouse space on Brannan and 7th. ForestGreen played, and Popgirl again, and my friend Scott played some hard 90's acid trance from Denmark, I think. 
   
  This was, without a doubt, the most underground underground I have been. It was literally in a stinking, moldy basement full of cigarette smoke, blinking lights and strobes abound, and packed with 18-year old candy ravers absolutely rolling their asses off. My friends and I are all in our 30's and arrived sober. We were hugged and giggled upon as soon as we arrived, and looked around delighted and agog at the spectacle of pacifiers, toys, blinkies, stuffed animals and dry humping all over the floor. Conga lines of b-boys in baggy pants, pretending to sit in the 'car' that someone was 'driving', little girls with animal backpacks holding hands and staring at the twirling lights, a gorgeous young thing who danced with me with melting brown eyes and a bambi smile, puddles of people on the filthy floor, the endless blinkies in my face as I danced, mistaking my energy for anything other than natural adrenaline. It was like raver preschool. I say this with love - seriously, it
 was hilarious. I haven't seen a pacifier on the dance floor in years, and it was like - oh god, just took us all back. We were the only sober adults who could talk to the police when they arrived (just a friendly party, no worries, no closure!), we danced hard and handed out gum and water bottles, and just looked at the new generation of kids doing their thing on a Friday night. We stayed until the smell got the best of us and left the young'ns to party the night away in the dank basement. I'm very proud of Rocky - he did a great job. 
   
  Freaking pacifiers - heelarious! Ah, to be that young again..
   
  KFH

Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
  and how'd that treat you?

-&e->worth of seeds:

-&e->of research into super-efficient gardening and soil science. by their
-&e->calculations, once you get your garden established, you can grow all of the
-&e->fruits & veggies to support a family of four on something like 2,000 square
-&e->feet of land.

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?

Sweet story!

----- Original Message ----
From: Kleiner Fallhammer <carpetelf@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, June 12, 2006 6:47:45 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?

You know, I actually had a rather unexpectedly remarkable Friday night. Started at UndergroundSF to join my friends in visiting their oldest and dearest friend Jen from Maine  - http://www.popgirl23.com/. We were just about the only people there, and we danced our asses off all over the floor while she played some lovely house. Fun!
   
  Then, my friend Rocky was throwing his first ever underground in a warehouse space on Brannan and 7th. ForestGreen played, and Popgirl again, and my friend Scott played some hard 90's acid trance from Denmark, I think. 
   
  This was, without a doubt, the most underground underground I have been. It was literally in a stinking, moldy basement full of cigarette smoke, blinking lights and strobes abound, and packed with 18-year old candy ravers absolutely rolling their asses off. My friends and I are all in our 30's and arrived sober. We were hugged and giggled upon as soon as we arrived, and looked around delighted and agog at the spectacle of pacifiers, toys, blinkies, stuffed animals and dry humping all over the floor. Conga lines of b-boys in baggy pants, pretending to sit in the 'car' that someone was 'driving', little girls with animal backpacks holding hands and staring at the twirling lights, a gorgeous young thing who danced with me with melting brown eyes and a bambi smile, puddles of people on the filthy floor, the endless blinkies in my face as I danced, mistaking my energy for anything other than natural adrenaline. It was like raver preschool. I say this with love - seriously, it
 was hilarious. I haven't seen a pacifier on the dance floor in years, and it was like - oh god, just took us all back. We were the only sober adults who could talk to the police when they arrived (just a friendly party, no worries, no closure!), we danced hard and handed out gum and water bottles, and just looked at the new generation of kids doing their thing on a Friday night. We stayed until the smell got the best of us and left the young'ns to party the night away in the dank basement. I'm very proud of Rocky - he did a great job. 
   
  Freaking pacifiers - heelarious! Ah, to be that young again..
   
  KFH

Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
  and how'd that treat you?

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

May 12th: Under Construction @ Suede
May 13th: So You Want Some Breaks? @ Butter
May 20th: DIRTY w/ Circuitbreaker @ Jelly's

i am a huge proponent of the idea that old ravers need to be
reintroduced to the young raver vibe every so often.

it's a kick in the pants to stop acting jaded and elitist and to
remember a more innocent time of fun.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?

old ravers = you, nico

;)

On 6/13/06, nico <nico@viberation.com> wrote:
> Define "old ravers"?  Geriatric or what?
>
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?
>
>
> >i am a huge proponent of the idea that old ravers need to be
> > reintroduced to the young raver vibe every so often.
> >
> > it's a kick in the pants to stop acting jaded and elitist and to
> > remember a more innocent time of fun.
> >
> > On 6/12/06, Kleiner Fallhammer <carpetelf@yahoo.com> wrote:
> >> You know, I actually had a rather unexpectedly remarkable Friday night.
> >> Started at UndergroundSF to join my friends in visiting their oldest and
> >> dearest friend Jen from Maine  - http://www.popgirl23.com/. We were just
> >> about the only people there, and we danced our asses off all over the
> >> floor while she played some lovely house. Fun!
> >>
> >>   Then, my friend Rocky was throwing his first ever underground in a
> >> warehouse space on Brannan and 7th. ForestGreen played, and Popgirl
> >> again, and my friend Scott played some hard 90's acid trance from
> >> Denmark, I think.
> >>
> >>   This was, without a doubt, the most underground underground I have
> >> been. It was literally in a stinking, moldy basement full of cigarette
> >> smoke, blinking lights and strobes abound, and packed with 18-year old
> >> candy ravers absolutely rolling their asses off. My friends and I are all
> >> in our 30's and arrived sober. We were hugged and giggled upon as soon as
> >> we arrived, and looked around delighted and agog at the spectacle of
> >> pacifiers, toys, blinkies, stuffed animals and dry humping all over the
> >> floor. Conga lines of b-boys in baggy pants, pretending to sit in the
> >> 'car' that someone was 'driving', little girls with animal backpacks
> >> holding hands and staring at the twirling lights, a gorgeous young thing
> >> who danced with me with melting brown eyes and a bambi smile, puddles of
> >> people on the filthy floor, the endless blinkies in my face as I danced,
> >> mistaking my energy for anything other than natural adrenaline. It was
> >> like raver preschool. I say this with love - seriously, it
> >>  was hilarious. I haven't seen a pacifier on the dance floor in years,
> >> and it was like - oh god, just took us all back. We were the only sober
> >> adults who could talk to the police when they arrived (just a friendly
> >> party, no worries, no closure!), we danced hard and handed out gum and
> >> water bottles, and just looked at the new generation of kids doing their
> >> thing on a Friday night. We stayed until the smell got the best of us and
> >> left the young'ns to party the night away in the dank basement. I'm very
> >> proud of Rocky - he did a great job.
> >>
> >>   Freaking pacifiers - heelarious! Ah, to be that young again..
> >>
> >>   KFH
> >>
> >> Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
> >>   and how'd that treat you?

Electro Revolution Presents:=20

SACRAMENTO SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL
Concert . Campout . Party

www.sacramentomusicfestival.com

Infoline: (916)771-0186

Gates Open on 6/22 @ 5pm sharp!

The First Annual Sacramento Summer Music Festival
SSMF 2006
Dub Star Universal

SATURDAY SUNDAY=20
July 22 - 23, 2006
MARYSVILLE, CALIFORNIA
www.SacramentoMusicFestival.com


Electro-Revolution Experience
The first Annual Sacramento Summer Music Festival or simply the =
Electro-Revolution as its become known as, is the summer installment of =
the largest electronic dance event in the Sacramento area. With a =
massive variety of music, artists, performers and music lovers from =
around the world, it is an experience that is unique and enduring for =
all those who love electronic dance music.


It is the Electro-Revolution Experience that we invite you to enjoy with =
all of your friends, family and soon to be friends. After searching =
across northern California camp sites Dub Star Universal has chosen a =
site that will allow us to create an event that is true to the out door =
experience. Camping, dancing, and enjoying the company of friends and =
everything else that the Electro-Revolution Experience can only be =
enhanced by the presence of the hot sun and the bright stars!=20

Dub Star Universal will be transforming the Electro-Revolution =
Experience to a themed environment that will create a completely new =
level of connection and interaction with the music, the land and each =
other. All performance stages will be themed.=20

The Sacramento Summer Music Festival is presented by:=20
Dub Star Universal & Friends



With performances by:=20

Main Stage
brought to you by Dub Star Universal=20

From: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>

Electro Revolution Presents:

SACRAMENTO SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL
Concert . Campout . Party

www.sacramentomusicfestival.com

Infoline: (916)771-0186

Gates Open on 6/22 @ 5pm sharp!

The First Annual Sacramento Summer Music Festival
SSMF 2006
Dub Star Universal

SATURDAY SUNDAY
July 22 - 23, 2006
MARYSVILLE, CALIFORNIA
www.SacramentoMusicFestival.com


Electro-Revolution Experience
The first Annual Sacramento Summer Music Festival or simply the 
Electro-Revolution as its become known as, is the summer installment of the 
largest electronic dance event in the Sacramento area. With a massive 
variety of music, artists, performers and music lovers from around the 
world, it is an experience that is unique and enduring for all those who 
love electronic dance music.


It is the Electro-Revolution Experience that we invite you to enjoy with all 
of your friends, family and soon to be friends. After searching across 
northern California camp sites Dub Star Universal has chosen a site that 
will allow us to create an event that is true to the out door experience. 
Camping, dancing, and enjoying the company of friends and everything else 
that the Electro-Revolution Experience can only be enhanced by the presence 
of the hot sun and the bright stars!

Dub Star Universal will be transforming the Electro-Revolution Experience to 
a themed environment that will create a completely new level of connection 
and interaction with the music, the land and each other. All performance 
stages will be themed.

The Sacramento Summer Music Festival is presented by:
Dub Star Universal & Friends



With performances by:

Main Stage
brought to you by Dub Star Universal

Cascada (Germany)
D.H.T. (Belgium)
Ian Van Dahl (Belgium)
Lisa Pin-Up (Tidy Girls, United Kingdom)
Amber D (Tidy Trax, United Kingdom)

committed to producing Quality events from internationally headlined shows, 
club nights to underground electronic music parties. These events range from 
700 to 12,000 people.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?

--0-2082273259-1150216914=:23590
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I went to this 3 day camp out thing way out in the middle of no where. It was kick ass. I got there and was like wtf is this. There was Psy trance and some other stuff and some other stuff. So I'm walking around and I go to the psy trance sound stage, they were playing some good beats. Out of no where some hippie dude comes up to me and puts his hand out, I was like he wants to shake my hand? I put my hand out and he slaps this friggin fat ass nug into my hand and walks away. I was like whoah, this is the most kick ass thing thats ever happend to me. He asked me if I wanted anything to eat, I got like an Orange it was coo. I came hella unpreparied. I basicly just came with the clothes on my back. Me and my friend were post to get there at like 10-12 am on friday night but didnt end up getting there till 5am on sat. We were gonna stay there for just 1 night. THe trip there was crazy the nearest store was like 40-60 miles away, I didnt think it was that so I was assed out. So
 after that guy gave me that I start walking around chopping it up with other people, I was so happy when the guy gave me that I wanted to share that experince with everyone else around me. I went around and smoked out everyone I possibly could. I was gone. After a while I went to the spot where my friend set up camp. Me and a group other people were posted there for a good bit. There was people from all over the fucking place, out of the state, people not from the us. Everyone had good vibes. I was chillin by the camp fire and some girl comes up to me and asked me if I wanted to chill I was like aight. We head over to the chill area and she starts feeding me food! I was like what! what! It was like I was in heaven. The thing that tripped me out the most was that everyone left there stuff out in the open. No one jacked anything from anyone. Like everytime I go to a partie you had to keep your shit on lock down or you would lose it. This partie was different. The only thing
 that was being taken were good vibes, good vibes being taken and passed around. Going to these types of parties gives ya a different perspective on things. Everyone should just be chill, hugs and hand shakes for everyone! Its nice to know theres people out there like this. I'm gonna stop typing and get some breakfest. Everyone have a good week.

Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:  and how'd that treat you?

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

May 12th: Under Construction @ Suede
May 13th: So You Want Some Breaks? @ Butter
May 20th: DIRTY w/ Circuitbreaker @ Jelly's

From: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 6/22 - 6/23 - Sacramento Summer Music Festival!!!


Electro Revolution Presents:

SACRAMENTO SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL
Concert . Campout . Party

www.sacramentomusicfestival.com

Infoline: (916)771-0186

Gates Open on 7/22 @ 5pm sharp!

The First Annual Sacramento Summer Music Festival
SSMF 2006
Dub Star Universal

SATURDAY SUNDAY
July 22 - 23, 2006
MARYSVILLE, CALIFORNIA
www.SacramentoMusicFestival.com


Electro-Revolution Experience
The first Annual Sacramento Summer Music Festival or simply the 
Electro-Revolution as its become known as, is the summer installment of the 
largest electronic dance event in the Sacramento area. With a massive 
variety of music, artists, performers and music lovers from around the 
world, it is an experience that is unique and enduring for all those who 
love electronic dance music.


It is the Electro-Revolution Experience that we invite you to enjoy with all 
of your friends, family and soon to be friends. After searching across 
northern California camp sites Dub Star Universal has chosen a site that 
will allow us to create an event that is true to the out door experience. 
Camping, dancing, and enjoying the company of friends and everything else 
that the Electro-Revolution Experience can only be enhanced by the presence 
of the hot sun and the bright stars!

Dub Star Universal will be transforming the Electro-Revolution Experience to 
a themed environment that will create a completely new level of connection 
and interaction with the music, the land and each other. All performance 
stages will be themed.

The Sacramento Summer Music Festival is presented by:
Dub Star Universal & Friends



With performances by:

brought to you by Dub Star Universal

LEFTISM CD RELEASE PARTY |/ FRIDAY, JUNE 16

=EF=BF=BC
Ladies and gentleman...and lowlifes: it is with outstanding pleasure =20
that we bring to you to the Bay Area release party for Leftism. Back =20
story: in March, Left Coast knockout kings J-Boogie and Sake1nce =20
collaborated on a quick, live mix CD to use to promote a gig at =20
Winter Music Conference in Miami. The CD caused a buzz in Miami among =20=

tastemakers, and the boys decided to produce the CD on a wider scale, =20=

with the support of the fellow Jedi Knighs from Fresco. Join J-=20
Boogie, Sake One and Fresco Selectors Tokyo Component, Hakobo & Kento =20=

as we motivate booties this Friday @ Frisco's fly new spot, BOCA (Bar =20=

of Contemporary Art) =E2=80=A2 414 Jessie (at 5th street; up the block =
from =20
Mezzanine) =E2=80=A2 21+ with ID. Dress How You Dress. $10 cover =E2=80=A2=
 =20
10p-2a =E2=80=A2 First 50 people thru tha door get a free copy of the =
CD!!

=EF=BF=BC
LEFTISM TRACK LISTING

=EF=BF=BC

=EF=BF=BC

=EF=BF=BC
=E2=80=A2Thursday, June 15: PST feat. guest DJ Henroc + fundraiser for =
the =20
Venceremos Brigade. 1710 Mission Street, 10p-2a.
=E2=80=A2Baby Loves Disco: Daytime dance party for parents and their =
cute =20
ass kids! Free stroller parking & snacks. Sake One with the deep (and =20=

shallow) disco classiques from 2p-5p. At Ruby Skye, 420 Mason Street, =20=

SF.
=E2=80=A2Saturday, June 17: Enter the Dancehall feat. Sake One, I-Vier, =
Ras =20
Cue, Doogie & more + live performance by Binghi Ghost. Club Six =20
(going after hours)


--Apple-Mail-4-117710553

Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?

I'm ready!  There's just one problem: no babysitter.

Maybe the old schoolers can trade the candy ravers for some babysitting services?   Hmm.

No pacifier sharing puleez!

Peace,

Peter

P.S. Actually none of my kids has ever used a pacifier but that's not funny.  

P.P.S. Also I'm serious.  We will pay good money to a trustworthy babysitter.

----- Original Message ----
From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: Kleiner Fallhammer <carpetelf@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, June 13, 2006 9:09:57 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?

i am a huge proponent of the idea that old ravers need to be
reintroduced to the young raver vibe every so often.

it's a kick in the pants to stop acting jaded and elitist and to
remember a more innocent time of fun.

On 6/12/06, Kleiner Fallhammer <carpetelf@yahoo.com> wrote:
> You know, I actually had a rather unexpectedly remarkable Friday night. Started at UndergroundSF to join my friends in visiting their oldest and dearest friend Jen from Maine  - http://www.popgirl23.com/. We were just about the only people there, and we danced our asses off all over the floor while she played some lovely house. Fun!
>
>   Then, my friend Rocky was throwing his first ever underground in a warehouse space on Brannan and 7th. ForestGreen played, and Popgirl again, and my friend Scott played some hard 90's acid trance from Denmark, I think.
>
>   This was, without a doubt, the most underground underground I have been. It was literally in a stinking, moldy basement full of cigarette smoke, blinking lights and strobes abound, and packed with 18-year old candy ravers absolutely rolling their asses off. My friends and I are all in our 30's and arrived sober. We were hugged and giggled upon as soon as we arrived, and looked around delighted and agog at the spectacle of pacifiers, toys, blinkies, stuffed animals and dry humping all over the floor. Conga lines of b-boys in baggy pants, pretending to sit in the 'car' that someone was 'driving', little girls with animal backpacks holding hands and staring at the twirling lights, a gorgeous young thing who danced with me with melting brown eyes and a bambi smile, puddles of people on the filthy floor, the endless blinkies in my face as I danced, mistaking my energy for anything other than natural adrenaline. It was like raver preschool. I say this with love - seriously,
 it
>  was hilarious. I haven't seen a pacifier on the dance floor in years, and it was like - oh god, just took us all back. We were the only sober adults who could talk to the police when they arrived (just a friendly party, no worries, no closure!), we danced hard and handed out gum and water bottles, and just looked at the new generation of kids doing their thing on a Friday night. We stayed until the smell got the best of us and left the young'ns to party the night away in the dank basement. I'm very proud of Rocky - he did a great job.
>
>   Freaking pacifiers - heelarious! Ah, to be that young again..
>
>   KFH
>
> Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
>   and how'd that treat you?
>
> --
> --------------------------
> < Brandon / DJ Bam >
>
> DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> http://www.evilbreaks.com
>
> May 12th: Under Construction @ Suede
> May 13th: So You Want Some Breaks? @ Butter
> May 20th: DIRTY w/ Circuitbreaker @ Jelly's

> >> thing who danced with me with melting brown eyes
> and
> >> a bambi smile, puddles of people on the filthy
> >> floor, the endless blinkies in my face as I
> danced,
> >> mistaking my energy for anything other than
> natural
> >> adrenaline. It was like raver preschool. I say
> this
> >> with love - seriously,
> >>  it
> >> >  was hilarious. I haven't seen a pacifier on
> the
> >> dance floor in years, and it was like - oh god,
> just
> >> took us all back. We were the only sober adults
> who
> >> could talk to the police when they arrived (just
> a
> >> friendly party, no worries, no closure!), we
> danced
> >> hard and handed out gum and water bottles, and
> just
> >> looked at the new generation of kids doing their
> >> thing on a Friday night. We stayed until the
> smell
> >> got the best of us and left the young'ns to party
> >> the night away in the dank basement. I'm very
> proud
> >> of Rocky - he did a great job.
> >> >
> >> >   Freaking pacifiers - heelarious! Ah, to be
> that
> >> young again..
> >> >
> >> >   KFH
> >> >
> >> > Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
> >> >   and how'd that treat you?
> >> >
> >> > --
> >> > --------------------------

Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?





i <3 your story, Kleiner Fallhammer!

i'm older than you and actually i did drugs back in the 60s but haven't
since the 70s so all my raving's been sober and i totally love what you
said - that's the way it's always been for me, lol - i love the new kids,
too - their fresh energy, that they are the inheritors of what i felt when
i was newbie in '95 - i love and respect them so much for 'getting it'  :)

thank you and much respect and appreciation,
mary :)

----- Original Message ----
From: Kleiner Fallhammer <carpetelf@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, June 12, 2006 6:47:45 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?

You know, I actually had a rather unexpectedly remarkable Friday night.
Started at UndergroundSF to join my friends in visiting their oldest and
dearest friend Jen from Maine  - http://www.popgirl23.com/. We were just
about the only people there, and we danced our asses off all over the floor
while she played some lovely house. Fun!

  Then, my friend Rocky was throwing his first ever underground in a
warehouse space on Brannan and 7th. ForestGreen played, and Popgirl again,
and my friend Scott played some hard 90's acid trance from Denmark, I
think.

  This was, without a doubt, the most underground underground I have been.
It was literally in a stinking, moldy basement full of cigarette smoke,
blinking lights and strobes abound, and packed with 18-year old candy
ravers absolutely rolling their asses off. My friends and I are all in our
30's and arrived sober. We were hugged and giggled upon as soon as we
arrived, and looked around delighted and agog at the spectacle of
pacifiers, toys, blinkies, stuffed animals and dry humping all over the
floor. Conga lines of b-boys in baggy pants, pretending to sit in the 'car'
that someone was 'driving', little girls with animal backpacks holding
hands and staring at the twirling lights, a gorgeous young thing who danced
with me with melting brown eyes and a bambi smile, puddles of people on the
filthy floor, the endless blinkies in my face as I danced, mistaking my
energy for anything other than natural adrenaline. It was like raver
preschool. I say this with love - seriously, it
 was hilarious. I haven't seen a pacifier on the dance floor in years, and
it was like - oh god, just took us all back. We were the only sober adults
who could talk to the police when they arrived (just a friendly party, no
worries, no closure!), we danced hard and handed out gum and water bottles,
and just looked at the new generation of kids doing their thing on a Friday
night. We stayed until the smell got the best of us and left the young'ns
to party the night away in the dank basement. I'm very proud of Rocky - he
did a great job.

  Freaking pacifiers - heelarious! Ah, to be that young again..

  KFH


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>
>
>
>
> i <3 your story, Kleiner Fallhammer!
>
> i'm older than you and actually i did drugs back in the 60s but haven't
> since the 70s so all my raving's been sober and i totally love what you
> said - that's the way it's always been for me, lol - i love the new kids,
> too - their fresh energy, that they are the inheritors of what i felt when
> i was newbie in '95 - i love and respect them so much for 'getting it'  :)
>
> thank you and much respect and appreciation,
> mary :)
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Kleiner Fallhammer <carpetelf@yahoo.com>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Monday, June 12, 2006 6:47:45 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] who raved this weekend?
>
> You know, I actually had a rather unexpectedly remarkable Friday night.
> Started at UndergroundSF to join my friends in visiting their oldest and
> dearest friend Jen from Maine  - http://www.popgirl23.com/. We were just
> about the only people there, and we danced our asses off all over the 
> floor
> while she played some lovely house. Fun!
>
>  Then, my friend Rocky was throwing his first ever underground in a
> warehouse space on Brannan and 7th. ForestGreen played, and Popgirl again,
> and my friend Scott played some hard 90's acid trance from Denmark, I
> think.
>
>  This was, without a doubt, the most underground underground I have been.
> It was literally in a stinking, moldy basement full of cigarette smoke,
> blinking lights and strobes abound, and packed with 18-year old candy
> ravers absolutely rolling their asses off. My friends and I are all in our
> 30's and arrived sober. We were hugged and giggled upon as soon as we
> arrived, and looked around delighted and agog at the spectacle of
> pacifiers, toys, blinkies, stuffed animals and dry humping all over the
> floor. Conga lines of b-boys in baggy pants, pretending to sit in the 
> 'car'
> that someone was 'driving', little girls with animal backpacks holding
> hands and staring at the twirling lights, a gorgeous young thing who 
> danced
> with me with melting brown eyes and a bambi smile, puddles of people on 
> the
> filthy floor, the endless blinkies in my face as I danced, mistaking my
> energy for anything other than natural adrenaline. It was like raver
> preschool. I say this with love - seriously, it
> was hilarious. I haven't seen a pacifier on the dance floor in years, and
> it was like - oh god, just took us all back. We were the only sober adults
> who could talk to the police when they arrived (just a friendly party, no
> worries, no closure!), we danced hard and handed out gum and water 
> bottles,
> and just looked at the new generation of kids doing their thing on a 
> Friday
> night. We stayed until the smell got the best of us and left the young'ns
> to party the night away in the dank basement. I'm very proud of Rocky - he
> did a great job.
>
>  Freaking pacifiers - heelarious! Ah, to be that young again..
>
>  KFH
>
>
