> Wow, this place sounds like an awful waste of money.  I thought "ultra 
> lounges" in the city were bad...
>
> Bottle/table service is the wackest thing since Hypercolors..  I just 
> can't imagine why anybody'd feel like a pimp just because they paid $300 
> for a $20 bottle of liquor and the sainted right to sit at a tiny table. 
> I can throw a wicked house party for 30 people for not a whole lot more 
> than $300.  I guess if one has enough money that $300 is a trifle and 
> they'd rather sit and mix their own drinks than go, say, dance, or trouble 
> themselves by going to, say, the bar for a drink, then, hey, that's a 
> great entertainment value!  Meh.  Exclusivity by design, not by function. 
> It's like selling gold-plated turds.
>
> "Hey, have you seen my new Fendi turd?  It's dipped in platinum!  Cost a 
> cool 2 Gs.."
>
> "Yeck, I think I can smell it through the coating.  Fendi, though, huh? 
> Pretty fly.."
>
> "Yeah, it's from the 'Affluent Effluent' series, the girls LOVE IT."
>
> "Oh yeah, I think I'm going to pick up their new donkey piss-filled 
> zirconium-encrusted money clip soon."
>
> "Score bro!" *hi5*
>
> Personally, I think megaclubs with megaqueues and guest list politics are 
> the penultiwack.  I've played a few of them and inside it's always the 
> same- moneyed idiots that can't dance and the golddiggers that magnetize 
> to them, all surrounded by bad architecture, tasteless attire, and vibe in 
> the sub-zero range.  For all of their external bling, most of these places 
> have substandard dj booths, pay performers horribly, and offer paltry 
> niceties to the talent- but that's just a dj's perspective.
>
> Anyway, not to rain on your parade- it was just funny that you seemed to 
> have a good time and like the place despite a "if you dance by my table 
> and you don't know me you're getting the boot" attitude..  Just sounds 
> like postureville to me.  Glad you had fun though.
>
> -vegas-hater

> From: Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com>

> Tryst is amazing..  you know how endup has this little waterfall outside..
> okay.. imagine about $500 mill to beef that up to a 100 foot three level
> casading actual water fall.. with a pool at the bottom and the whole thing
> is lined against the outside walls with white lounge tables.  Then throw 
> in
> about 10 bars, stripper poles, hot hot hot hot women, and some pretty nice
> people all around all after the same thing.  The sound was great, the
> lighting excellent,
>
> I was supposed to be on the guest list, and when I rolled up to the spot
> there were like 300 people clammoring to get in.  I heard from two people
> that the way in is 1) know someone, and 2) through the doormen.  Once I
> dialed in who was working the list.. it was all  gravy.  I made sure to go
> to the cash machine for $100 in fives, and then started handing em out 
> like
> candy.  Ya.. that worked.  Sometimes rolling solo is so much easier.. 
> there
> is no group complication and it is just easier for people to deal with 
> you.
> I kinda had the feeling last night that is what got me in the door since I
> found I wasn't on the list.. yeah for style points.
>
> It was funny how people (girls) that danced on the platforms had to be
> smokingly hot to be up there.. or they would be asked to leave.  It was
> funny how I had to know somebody in the group to be dancing by their table
> or I would be asked to leave.   People are straight up - who do you know,
> why are you here (on a thurday night).  At the end of the night, the only
> people I really vibed on was this married chica and I don't do that.. but 
> I
> am down for meeting new people so I still made the connect.  I also 
> learned
> how to play three card poker and won $80 for my first time gambling.. easy
> to stop when your up right?

>Wow, this place sounds like an awful waste of money.  I thought "ultra 
>lounges" in the city were bad...
>
>Bottle/table service is the wackest thing since Hypercolors..  I just can't 
>imagine why anybody'd feel like a pimp just because they paid $300 for a 
>$20 bottle of liquor and the sainted right to sit at a tiny table. I can 
>throw a wicked house party for 30 people for not a whole lot more than 
>$300.  I guess if one has enough money that $300 is a trifle and they'd 
>rather sit and mix their own drinks than go, say, dance, or trouble 
>themselves by going to, say, the bar for a drink, then, hey, that's a great 
>entertainment value!  Meh.  Exclusivity by design, not by function. It's 
>like selling gold-plated turds.
>
>"Hey, have you seen my new Fendi turd?  It's dipped in platinum!  Cost a 
>cool 2 Gs.."
>
>"Yeck, I think I can smell it through the coating.  Fendi, though, huh? 
>Pretty fly.."
>
>"Yeah, it's from the 'Affluent Effluent' series, the girls LOVE IT."
>
>"Oh yeah, I think I'm going to pick up their new donkey piss-filled 
>zirconium-encrusted money clip soon."
>
>"Score bro!" *hi5*
>
>Personally, I think megaclubs with megaqueues and guest list politics are 
>the penultiwack.  I've played a few of them and inside it's always the 
>same- moneyed idiots that can't dance and the golddiggers that magnetize to 
>them, all surrounded by bad architecture, tasteless attire, and vibe in the 
>sub-zero range.  For all of their external bling, most of these places have 
>substandard dj booths, pay performers horribly, and offer paltry niceties 
>to the talent- but that's just a dj's perspective.
>
>Anyway, not to rain on your parade- it was just funny that you seemed to 
>have a good time and like the place despite a "if you dance by my table and 
>you don't know me you're getting the boot" attitude..  Just sounds like 
>postureville to me.  Glad you had fun though.
>
>-vegas-hater

>From: Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com>

>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

>Tryst is amazing..  you know how endup has this little waterfall outside..
>okay.. imagine about $500 mill to beef that up to a 100 foot three level
>casading actual water fall.. with a pool at the bottom and the whole thing
>is lined against the outside walls with white lounge tables.  Then throw in
>about 10 bars, stripper poles, hot hot hot hot women, and some pretty nice
>people all around all after the same thing.  The sound was great, the
>lighting excellent,
>
>I was supposed to be on the guest list, and when I rolled up to the spot
>there were like 300 people clammoring to get in.  I heard from two people
>that the way in is 1) know someone, and 2) through the doormen.  Once I
>dialed in who was working the list.. it was all  gravy.  I made sure to go
>to the cash machine for $100 in fives, and then started handing em out like
>candy.  Ya.. that worked.  Sometimes rolling solo is so much easier.. there
>is no group complication and it is just easier for people to deal with you.
>I kinda had the feeling last night that is what got me in the door since I
>found I wasn't on the list.. yeah for style points.
>
>It was funny how people (girls) that danced on the platforms had to be
>smokingly hot to be up there.. or they would be asked to leave.  It was
>funny how I had to know somebody in the group to be dancing by their table
>or I would be asked to leave.   People are straight up - who do you know,
>why are you here (on a thurday night).  At the end of the night, the only
>people I really vibed on was this married chica and I don't do that.. but I
>am down for meeting new people so I still made the connect.  I also learned
>how to play three card poker and won $80 for my first time gambling.. easy
>to stop when your up right?
>
>More later, I have a headache :/

Wow do you miss the point....

10 people go out together, everyone pitches in a
hundred dollars, no one cares if you dance next to the
table, you'd probably be invited to stay if you did,
and everyone has a good time.

Its funny how people make assumptions about things
they've never tried....

And..... for the most part, we all hate bottle service
too... Just one of the things you have to lerarn to
deal with if you want to go out here... And guess
what, its gonna take over SF too, because they (The
club owners) make so much more off it.

Lastly, I had a great time meeting Sean, we all
enjoyed his company.

E

> Bottle/table service is the wackest thing since
> Hypercolors..  I just can't imagine why anybody'd

> 30 people for not a whole lot more than $300.  I
> guess if one has enough money that $300 is a trifle
> and they'd rather sit and mix their own drinks than
> go, say, dance, or trouble themselves by going to,
> say, the bar for a drink, then, hey, that's a great
> entertainment value!  Meh.  Exclusivity by design,
> not by function.  It's like selling gold-plated
> turds.
> 
> "Hey, have you seen my new Fendi turd?  It's dipped
> in platinum!  Cost a cool 2 Gs.."
> 
> "Yeck, I think I can smell it through the coating. 
> Fendi, though, huh?  Pretty fly.."
> 
> "Yeah, it's from the 'Affluent Effluent' series, the
> girls LOVE IT."
> 
> "Oh yeah, I think I'm going to pick up their new
> donkey piss-filled zirconium-encrusted money clip
> soon."
> 
> "Score bro!" *hi5*
> 
> Personally, I think megaclubs with megaqueues and
> guest list politics are the penultiwack.  I've
> played a few of them and inside it's always the
> same- moneyed idiots that can't dance and the
> golddiggers that magnetize to them, all surrounded
> by bad architecture, tasteless attire, and vibe in
> the sub-zero range.  For all of their external
> bling, most of these places have substandard dj
> booths, pay performers horribly, and offer paltry
> niceties to the talent- but that's just a dj's
> perspective.
> 
> Anyway, not to rain on your parade- it was just
> funny that you seemed to have a good time and like
> the place despite a "if you dance by my table and
> you don't know me you're getting the boot"
> attitude..  Just sounds like postureville to me. 
> Glad you had fun though.
> 
> -vegas-hater
>

> Tryst is amazing..  you know how endup has this
> little waterfall outside.. 
> okay.. imagine about $500 mill to beef that up to a
> 100 foot three level 
> casading actual water fall.. with a pool at the

> is lined against the outside walls with white lounge

> about 10 bars, stripper poles, hot hot hot hot

> lighting excellent,
> 
> I was supposed to be on the guest list, and when I
> rolled up to the spot 
> there were like 300 people clammoring to get in.  I
> heard from two people 
> that the way in is 1) know someone, and 2) through
> the doormen.  Once I 
> dialed in who was working the list.. it was all 
> gravy.  I made sure to go 
> to the cash machine for $100 in fives, and then
> started handing em out like 
> candy.  Ya.. that worked.  Sometimes rolling solo is
> so much easier.. there 
> is no group complication and it is just easier for
> people to deal with you.  
> I kinda had the feeling last night that is what got
> me in the door since I 
> found I wasn't on the list.. yeah for style points.
> 
> It was funny how people (girls) that danced on the
> platforms had to be 
> smokingly hot to be up there.. or they would be
> asked to leave.  It was 
> funny how I had to know somebody in the group to be
> dancing by their table 
> or I would be asked to leave.   People are straight
> up - who do you know, 
> why are you here (on a thurday night).  At the end
> of the night, the only 
> people I really vibed on was this married chica and
> I don't do that.. but I 
> am down for meeting new people so I still made the
> connect.  I also learned 
> how to play three card poker and won $80 for my

> to stop when your up right?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

Since we top post here:

What would happen if there *was* a club with good architecture, great
fashion and awesome vibe? It seems whenever that happens, the same
people as below hear about it, take over and everybody leaves for a
new 'cool-but-not-cool' place.

I agree w/George on all points, but I would have no qualms owning one
of those wack clubs and taking their money - why argue with demand,
idiotic or not? :)

- Nic

On 6/26/06, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Wow, this place sounds like an awful waste of money.  I thought "ultra lounges" in the city were bad...
>
> Bottle/table service is the wackest thing since Hypercolors..  I just can't imagine why anybody'd feel like a pimp just because they paid $300 for a $20 bottle of liquor and the sainted right to sit at a tiny table.  I can throw a wicked house party for 30 people for not a whole lot more than $300.  I guess if one has enough money that $300 is a trifle and they'd rather sit and mix their own drinks than go, say, dance, or trouble themselves by going to, say, the bar for a drink, then, hey, that's a great entertainment value!  Meh.  Exclusivity by design, not by function.  It's like selling gold-plated turds.
>
> "Hey, have you seen my new Fendi turd?  It's dipped in platinum!  Cost a cool 2 Gs.."
>
> "Yeck, I think I can smell it through the coating.  Fendi, though, huh?  Pretty fly.."
>
> "Yeah, it's from the 'Affluent Effluent' series, the girls LOVE IT."
>
> "Oh yeah, I think I'm going to pick up their new donkey piss-filled zirconium-encrusted money clip soon."
>
> "Score bro!" *hi5*
>
> Personally, I think megaclubs with megaqueues and guest list politics are the penultiwack.  I've played a few of them and inside it's always the same- moneyed idiots that can't dance and the golddiggers that magnetize to them, all surrounded by bad architecture, tasteless attire, and vibe in the sub-zero range.  For all of their external bling, most of these places have substandard dj booths, pay performers horribly, and offer paltry niceties to the talent- but that's just a dj's perspective.
>
> Anyway, not to rain on your parade- it was just funny that you seemed to have a good time and like the place despite a "if you dance by my table and you don't know me you're getting the boot" attitude..  Just sounds like postureville to me.  Glad you had fun though.
>
> -vegas-hater

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

Figure I'll address both replies at once:

I'm not hating for the point of hating.  I frankly believe that table and bottle service is killing club culture, and I love clubbing, so it kills me to see this happen.  Open and shut.  Before this started creeping into clubs around here, by and large clubs were places you could go, with or without friends, with or without much money.  You could go, see great music, meet fun people, spend a little money on drinks or whatever you want, sit wherever you want, etc.  Clubs were designed to bring people together and foster social interaction.

Table/bottle service not only serves to cloister folks off in their own little worlds.  It also sets up a dichotomy of class where there never was one before- those who can afford the luxury box, and those who can't.  The social interaction aspect is de-emphasized, as is the music appreciation/dancing side of things.  The dancefloors at these places are smaller because many folks are just off doing their table thing and the sound systems are often terrible.  Some clubs have no seating at all besides at the rented tables.  What happened to having a place to take a breather after a couple of hours of hard dancing?  Oh yeah, get out the wallet.

The world, IMHO, is bifurcated enough.  Clubs always have stood as social blenders and transporters to another world- places to go to FORGET THE OUTSIDE WORLD for a little while.  When have-and-have-not segregation creeps into the picture, the "corporate" world creeps in with it.  Not only must you "dress to impress" (who?), you've got to pony up the scrill just to sit down.  Your needs as a consumer are not thought of.   It'd be like buying a Mercedes and finding out as the sale closed that the driver's seat is an extra grand.  

---

"Here are your keys, Mr. Morris, enjoy!"

"Hey, there's no driver's seat..  Where do I sit?"

"Sit?  Hmm, on the floor, I suppose, how should I know?"

"Normally there are things called seats in automobiles- drivers and passengers use them to sit in."

"Oh, you must be speaking about the Premium Posterior Support System!  Its padded, adjustable cushions provide exceedingly pleasurable seating for the driver who must have only the best.  Also included in this package is a seat belt, which can be of great help in keeping one's face out of the windshield in an accident!  That'll add one thousand dollars to the selling price.  A very good pick, sir!"  Etc etc...

---

Do you honestly think that comfortable places for people to sit and enjoy cocktails are something one should have to pay more (past the cover) for?  The clubs I go to have great seating, great drinks, and great music (better than most ultra lounges by a long yard).  The people who dreamed this sort of thing up are laughing all the way to the bank, folks.  I hate to stick in yet another dramatization, but this is how that conversation went:

---

"Yo, Vinnie, times are tough, how are we gonna get things going here?"

"Shit, I dunno..  Hey, you know all those booths we got that people like to sit in with friends?  How about if we put up signs that say 'by reservation only', and charge people a couple hundred bones to sit there?"

"Whoa, the crack must have been fresh this morning, Vinnie- why would anybody pay to sit down?"

"Well, we'll take all the rest of the chairs out, first off- and we'll redesign the club and the promo to imply that if you don't got a table, you're dirt, and you'd better start saving your pennies.  You know how those rich guys love to feel more important than everybody else- they'll love a chance at exclusivity in a place where they're usually too unclued and uncool to hang out!"

"Hey now, that's pretty smart- but if they're paying that kind of dosh just so sit down, they're not gonna wanna get up all the time.."

"..so we'll sell em a bottle of liquor we pay $10 for for another couple of hundred bucks, and throw in some 'complimentary' juice and soda, too!  That way the bartenders won't even have to service them!"

"Shit, you're a genius, pass that crackpipe.."

---

You go to a club with friends, you have some drinks, you are comfortable and you have a great time.  Would you have a better time if you paid to sit down, or if you had a nice place to sit down that didn't cost money?  I don't know about you, but when I go out, I go out to mingle, to meet new people, to dance, to enjoy my city's culture.  If I want to sit and down a bottle with some friends, I'll do it in my living room, at 1/10th the cost, where I can choose the music myself and hear my friends talking.  Call me crazy...

I create vibe wherever I go, too, Ranger, but I find it easier to have a good time when I'm not staring down both barrels of typical western money culture.  I throw parties, I've thrown raves, I have a monthly club event- hating on the scene?  No.  Hating on the corporatization of the scene?  Sure.

Hit me back when your favorite fancy restaurant starts handing you your filet mignon in a cone of newspaper and tells you it's gonna cost another $100 for a table and a place setting.  It's worse than corruption of a positive thing- it's simply terrible business and customer service.  At this point, all one can do is vote with one's dollar, and that's what I do.  As we speak, there are still plenty of prime places to club in SF that haven't fallen prey to this nonsense.

To each their own, and I'm happy that you're having fun and mean no disrespect.  If you must deal with this in the places you like to go, then more power to you and I commend your positive attitude- but don't try and tell me you think this is a positive trend.  Getting more for your money is never a bad thing.

Remember when you used to find out that the rave you were at had free fruit and water?  Wasn't that a nice feeling?  Would you rather have paid for it?  

-positive pedro

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "georgeC | origami" <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: "Eric Spire" <ericspire@yahoo.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, June 26, 2006 1:05 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update


> Figure I'll address both replies at once:
>
> I'm not hating for the point of hating.  I frankly believe that table and 
> bottle service is killing club culture, and I love clubbing, so it kills 
> me to see this happen.  Open and shut.  Before this started creeping into 
> clubs around here, by and large clubs were places you could go, with or 
> without friends, with or without much money.  You could go, see great 
> music, meet fun people, spend a little money on drinks or whatever you 
> want, sit wherever you want, etc.  Clubs were designed to bring people 
> together and foster social interaction.
>
> Table/bottle service not only serves to cloister folks off in their own 
> little worlds.  It also sets up a dichotomy of class where there never was 
> one before- those who can afford the luxury box, and those who can't.  The 
> social interaction aspect is de-emphasized, as is the music 
> appreciation/dancing side of things.  The dancefloors at these places are 
> smaller because many folks are just off doing their table thing and the 
> sound systems are often terrible.  Some clubs have no seating at all 
> besides at the rented tables.  What happened to having a place to take a 
> breather after a couple of hours of hard dancing?  Oh yeah, get out the 
> wallet.
>
> The world, IMHO, is bifurcated enough.  Clubs always have stood as social 
> blenders and transporters to another world- places to go to FORGET THE 
> OUTSIDE WORLD for a little while.  When have-and-have-not segregation 
> creeps into the picture, the "corporate" world creeps in with it.  Not 
> only must you "dress to impress" (who?), you've got to pony up the scrill 
> just to sit down.  Your needs as a consumer are not thought of.   It'd be 
> like buying a Mercedes and finding out as the sale closed that the 
> driver's seat is an extra grand.
>
> ---
>
> "Here are your keys, Mr. Morris, enjoy!"
>
> "Hey, there's no driver's seat..  Where do I sit?"
>
> "Sit?  Hmm, on the floor, I suppose, how should I know?"
>
> "Normally there are things called seats in automobiles- drivers and 
> passengers use them to sit in."
>
> "Oh, you must be speaking about the Premium Posterior Support System!  Its 
> padded, adjustable cushions provide exceedingly pleasurable seating for 
> the driver who must have only the best.  Also included in this package is 
> a seat belt, which can be of great help in keeping one's face out of the 
> windshield in an accident!  That'll add one thousand dollars to the 
> selling price.  A very good pick, sir!"  Etc etc...
>
> ---
>
> Do you honestly think that comfortable places for people to sit and enjoy 
> cocktails are something one should have to pay more (past the cover) for? 
> The clubs I go to have great seating, great drinks, and great music 
> (better than most ultra lounges by a long yard).  The people who dreamed 
> this sort of thing up are laughing all the way to the bank, folks.  I hate 
> to stick in yet another dramatization, but this is how that conversation 
> went:
>
> ---
>
> "Yo, Vinnie, times are tough, how are we gonna get things going here?"
>
> "Shit, I dunno..  Hey, you know all those booths we got that people like 
> to sit in with friends?  How about if we put up signs that say 'by 
> reservation only', and charge people a couple hundred bones to sit there?"
>
> "Whoa, the crack must have been fresh this morning, Vinnie- why would 
> anybody pay to sit down?"
>
> "Well, we'll take all the rest of the chairs out, first off- and we'll 
> redesign the club and the promo to imply that if you don't got a table, 
> you're dirt, and you'd better start saving your pennies.  You know how 
> those rich guys love to feel more important than everybody else- they'll 
> love a chance at exclusivity in a place where they're usually too unclued 
> and uncool to hang out!"
>
> "Hey now, that's pretty smart- but if they're paying that kind of dosh 
> just so sit down, they're not gonna wanna get up all the time.."
>
> "..so we'll sell em a bottle of liquor we pay $10 for for another couple 
> of hundred bucks, and throw in some 'complimentary' juice and soda, too! 
> That way the bartenders won't even have to service them!"
>
> "Shit, you're a genius, pass that crackpipe.."
>
> ---
>
> You go to a club with friends, you have some drinks, you are comfortable 
> and you have a great time.  Would you have a better time if you paid to 
> sit down, or if you had a nice place to sit down that didn't cost money? 
> I don't know about you, but when I go out, I go out to mingle, to meet new 
> people, to dance, to enjoy my city's culture.  If I want to sit and down a 
> bottle with some friends, I'll do it in my living room, at 1/10th the 
> cost, where I can choose the music myself and hear my friends talking. 
> Call me crazy...
>
> I create vibe wherever I go, too, Ranger, but I find it easier to have a 
> good time when I'm not staring down both barrels of typical western money 
> culture.  I throw parties, I've thrown raves, I have a monthly club event- 
> hating on the scene?  No.  Hating on the corporatization of the scene? 
> Sure.
>
> Hit me back when your favorite fancy restaurant starts handing you your 
> filet mignon in a cone of newspaper and tells you it's gonna cost another 
> $100 for a table and a place setting.  It's worse than corruption of a 
> positive thing- it's simply terrible business and customer service.  At 
> this point, all one can do is vote with one's dollar, and that's what I 
> do.  As we speak, there are still plenty of prime places to club in SF 
> that haven't fallen prey to this nonsense.
>
> To each their own, and I'm happy that you're having fun and mean no 
> disrespect.  If you must deal with this in the places you like to go, then 
> more power to you and I commend your positive attitude- but don't try and 
> tell me you think this is a positive trend.  Getting more for your money 
> is never a bad thing.
>
> Remember when you used to find out that the rave you were at had free 
> fruit and water?  Wasn't that a nice feeling?  Would you rather have paid 
> for it?
>
> -positive pedro
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

You're right, it's a great business idea!  I guess I protest more because I don't want to see clubs that *don't* extort like this edged out or forced to conform by clubs that do this.  Already there're a couple of places I used to love that are not worth visiting anymore due to this phenomenon.

The part I didn't touch on is the effect on the clientele this trend has had.  I'm not one to make generalizations, but my experience is that (my definitition of) people I like to club with don't really love hanging out in these places.  That's fine right now, but what if this was de rigeur?  Clubbing would be permanently changed, and in my opinion, not for the better.  

-GC

Since we top post here:

What would happen if there *was* a club with good architecture, great
fashion and awesome vibe? It seems whenever that happens, the same
people as below hear about it, take over and everybody leaves for a
new 'cool-but-not-cool' place.

I agree w/George on all points, but I would have no qualms owning one
of those wack clubs and taking their money - why argue with demand,
idiotic or not? :)

- Nic

From: Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

Hey... I actually totally agree with the
"hate-on-bottle-service" ideals... BUT... since there
is no choice here, you have to make the best of it,
and we do...

You have to look at it this way for us:
Drinks are $18 a piece.
Door is $30
So, door and 3 drinks with no place to chill is about
$100.

Table service gets you a place to chill, way more than
you can drink, and costs about the same...

Yeah it sucks, but if you go with a group of solid
friends, meet new people, and have a good time, it
works out just fine.

Finally, I agree about table service killing the vibe
in places like SF... its nitrous to the party... But
here, people dance on the chairs, the tables, the
poles, whatver... rather than make everyone sit down,
people make the best of their rented space....

Its all what you make of it.

E

--- georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:

> Figure I'll address both replies at once:
> 
> I'm not hating for the point of hating.  I frankly
> believe that table and bottle service is killing
> club culture, and I love clubbing, so it kills me to
> see this happen.  Open and shut.  Before this
> started creeping into clubs around here, by and
> large clubs were places you could go, with or
> without friends, with or without much money.  You
> could go, see great music, meet fun people, spend a
> little money on drinks or whatever you want, sit
> wherever you want, etc.  Clubs were designed to
> bring people together and foster social interaction.
> 
> Table/bottle service not only serves to cloister
> folks off in their own little worlds.  It also sets
> up a dichotomy of class where there never was one
> before- those who can afford the luxury box, and
> those who can't.  The social interaction aspect is
> de-emphasized, as is the music appreciation/dancing
> side of things.  The dancefloors at these places are
> smaller because many folks are just off doing their
> table thing and the sound systems are often
> terrible.  Some clubs have no seating at all besides
> at the rented tables.  What happened to having a
> place to take a breather after a couple of hours of
> hard dancing?  Oh yeah, get out the wallet.
> 
> The world, IMHO, is bifurcated enough.  Clubs always
> have stood as social blenders and transporters to
> another world- places to go to FORGET THE OUTSIDE
> WORLD for a little while.  When have-and-have-not
> segregation creeps into the picture, the "corporate"
> world creeps in with it.  Not only must you "dress
> to impress" (who?), you've got to pony up the scrill
> just to sit down.  Your needs as a consumer are not
> thought of.   It'd be like buying a Mercedes and
> finding out as the sale closed that the driver's
> seat is an extra grand.  
> 
> ---
> 
> "Here are your keys, Mr. Morris, enjoy!"
> 
> "Hey, there's no driver's seat..  Where do I sit?"
> 
> "Sit?  Hmm, on the floor, I suppose, how should I
> know?"
> 
> "Normally there are things called seats in
> automobiles- drivers and passengers use them to sit
> in."
> 
> "Oh, you must be speaking about the Premium
> Posterior Support System!  Its padded, adjustable
> cushions provide exceedingly pleasurable seating for
> the driver who must have only the best.  Also
> included in this package is a seat belt, which can
> be of great help in keeping one's face out of the
> windshield in an accident!  That'll add one thousand
> dollars to the selling price.  A very good pick,
> sir!"  Etc etc...
> 
> ---
> 
> Do you honestly think that comfortable places for
> people to sit and enjoy cocktails are something one
> should have to pay more (past the cover) for?  The
> clubs I go to have great seating, great drinks, and
> great music (better than most ultra lounges by a
> long yard).  The people who dreamed this sort of
> thing up are laughing all the way to the bank,
> folks.  I hate to stick in yet another
> dramatization, but this is how that conversation
> went:
> 
> ---
> 
> "Yo, Vinnie, times are tough, how are we gonna get
> things going here?"
> 
> "Shit, I dunno..  Hey, you know all those booths we
> got that people like to sit in with friends?  How
> about if we put up signs that say 'by reservation
> only', and charge people a couple hundred bones to
> sit there?"
> 
> "Whoa, the crack must have been fresh this morning,
> Vinnie- why would anybody pay to sit down?"
> 
> "Well, we'll take all the rest of the chairs out,
> first off- and we'll redesign the club and the promo
> to imply that if you don't got a table, you're dirt,
> and you'd better start saving your pennies.  You
> know how those rich guys love to feel more important
> than everybody else- they'll love a chance at
> exclusivity in a place where they're usually too
> unclued and uncool to hang out!"
> 
> "Hey now, that's pretty smart- but if they're paying
> that kind of dosh just so sit down, they're not
> gonna wanna get up all the time.."
> 
> "..so we'll sell em a bottle of liquor we pay $10
> for for another couple of hundred bucks, and throw
> in some 'complimentary' juice and soda, too!  That
> way the bartenders won't even have to service them!"
> 
> "Shit, you're a genius, pass that crackpipe.."
> 
> ---
> 
> You go to a club with friends, you have some drinks,
> you are comfortable and you have a great time. 
> Would you have a better time if you paid to sit
> down, or if you had a nice place to sit down that
> didn't cost money?  I don't know about you, but when
> I go out, I go out to mingle, to meet new people, to
> dance, to enjoy my city's culture.  If I want to sit
> and down a bottle with some friends, I'll do it in
> my living room, at 1/10th the cost, where I can
> choose the music myself and hear my friends talking.
>  Call me crazy...
> 
> I create vibe wherever I go, too, Ranger, but I find
> it easier to have a good time when I'm not staring
> down both barrels of typical western money culture. 
> I throw parties, I've thrown raves, I have a monthly
> club event- hating on the scene?  No.  Hating on the
> corporatization of the scene?  Sure.
> 
> Hit me back when your favorite fancy restaurant
> starts handing you your filet mignon in a cone of
> newspaper and tells you it's gonna cost another $100
> for a table and a place setting.  It's worse than
> corruption of a positive thing- it's simply terrible
> business and customer service.  At this point, all
> one can do is vote with one's dollar, and that's
> what I do.  As we speak, there are still plenty of
> prime places to club in SF that haven't fallen prey
> to this nonsense.
> 
> To each their own, and I'm happy that you're having
> fun and mean no disrespect.  If you must deal with
> this in the places you like to go, then more power
> to you and I commend your positive attitude- but
> don't try and tell me you think this is a positive
> trend.  Getting more for your money is never a bad
> thing.
> 
> Remember when you used to find out that the rave you
> were at had free fruit and water?  Wasn't that a
> nice feeling?  Would you rather have paid for it?  
> 
> -positive pedro
> 
>

----- Original Message ----
From: Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>
To: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>; Nic Werner <nicwerner@gmail.com>
Cc: Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, June 26, 2006 1:27:17 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

Hey... I actually totally agree with the
"hate-on-bottle-service" ideals... BUT... since there
is no choice here, you have to make the best of it,
and we do...

You have to look at it this way for us:
Drinks are $18 a piece.
Door is $30
So, door and 3 drinks with no place to chill is about
$100.

Table service gets you a place to chill, way more than
you can drink, and costs about the same...

Yeah it sucks, but if you go with a group of solid
friends, meet new people, and have a good time, it
works out just fine.

Finally, I agree about table service killing the vibe
in places like SF... its nitrous to the party... But
here, people dance on the chairs, the tables, the
poles, whatver... rather than make everyone sit down,
people make the best of their rented space....

Its all what you make of it.

E

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "georgeC | origami" <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: "Eric Spire" <ericspire@yahoo.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, June 26, 2006 1:05 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update


> Figure I'll address both replies at once:
>
> I'm not hating for the point of hating.  I frankly believe that table and 
> bottle service is killing club culture, and I love clubbing, so it kills 
> me to see this happen.  Open and shut.  Before this started creeping into 
> clubs around here, by and large clubs were places you could go, with or 
> without friends, with or without much money.  You could go, see great 
> music, meet fun people, spend a little money on drinks or whatever you 
> want, sit wherever you want, etc.  Clubs were designed to bring people 
> together and foster social interaction.
>
> Table/bottle service not only serves to cloister folks off in their own 
> little worlds.  It also sets up a dichotomy of class where there never was 
> one before- those who can afford the luxury box, and those who can't.  The 
> social interaction aspect is de-emphasized, as is the music 
> appreciation/dancing side of things.  The dancefloors at these places are 
> smaller because many folks are just off doing their table thing and the 
> sound systems are often terrible.  Some clubs have no seating at all 
> besides at the rented tables.  What happened to having a place to take a 
> breather after a couple of hours of hard dancing?  Oh yeah, get out the 
> wallet.
>
> The world, IMHO, is bifurcated enough.  Clubs always have stood as social 
> blenders and transporters to another world- places to go to FORGET THE 
> OUTSIDE WORLD for a little while.  When have-and-have-not segregation 
> creeps into the picture, the "corporate" world creeps in with it.  Not 
> only must you "dress to impress" (who?), you've got to pony up the scrill 
> just to sit down.  Your needs as a consumer are not thought of.   It'd be 
> like buying a Mercedes and finding out as the sale closed that the 
> driver's seat is an extra grand.
>
> ---
>
> "Here are your keys, Mr. Morris, enjoy!"
>
> "Hey, there's no driver's seat..  Where do I sit?"
>
> "Sit?  Hmm, on the floor, I suppose, how should I know?"
>
> "Normally there are things called seats in automobiles- drivers and 
> passengers use them to sit in."
>
> "Oh, you must be speaking about the Premium Posterior Support System!  Its 
> padded, adjustable cushions provide exceedingly pleasurable seating for 
> the driver who must have only the best.  Also included in this package is 
> a seat belt, which can be of great help in keeping one's face out of the 
> windshield in an accident!  That'll add one thousand dollars to the 
> selling price.  A very good pick, sir!"  Etc etc...
>
> ---
>
> Do you honestly think that comfortable places for people to sit and enjoy 
> cocktails are something one should have to pay more (past the cover) for? 
> The clubs I go to have great seating, great drinks, and great music 
> (better than most ultra lounges by a long yard).  The people who dreamed 
> this sort of thing up are laughing all the way to the bank, folks.  I hate 
> to stick in yet another dramatization, but this is how that conversation 
> went:
>
> ---
>
> "Yo, Vinnie, times are tough, how are we gonna get things going here?"
>
> "Shit, I dunno..  Hey, you know all those booths we got that people like 
> to sit in with friends?  How about if we put up signs that say 'by 
> reservation only', and charge people a couple hundred bones to sit there?"
>
> "Whoa, the crack must have been fresh this morning, Vinnie- why would 
> anybody pay to sit down?"
>
> "Well, we'll take all the rest of the chairs out, first off- and we'll 
> redesign the club and the promo to imply that if you don't got a table, 
> you're dirt, and you'd better start saving your pennies.  You know how 
> those rich guys love to feel more important than everybody else- they'll 
> love a chance at exclusivity in a place where they're usually too unclued 
> and uncool to hang out!"
>
> "Hey now, that's pretty smart- but if they're paying that kind of dosh 
> just so sit down, they're not gonna wanna get up all the time.."
>
> "..so we'll sell em a bottle of liquor we pay $10 for for another couple 
> of hundred bucks, and throw in some 'complimentary' juice and soda, too! 
> That way the bartenders won't even have to service them!"
>
> "Shit, you're a genius, pass that crackpipe.."
>
> ---
>
> You go to a club with friends, you have some drinks, you are comfortable 
> and you have a great time.  Would you have a better time if you paid to 
> sit down, or if you had a nice place to sit down that didn't cost money? 
> I don't know about you, but when I go out, I go out to mingle, to meet new 
> people, to dance, to enjoy my city's culture.  If I want to sit and down a 
> bottle with some friends, I'll do it in my living room, at 1/10th the 
> cost, where I can choose the music myself and hear my friends talking. 
> Call me crazy...
>
> I create vibe wherever I go, too, Ranger, but I find it easier to have a 
> good time when I'm not staring down both barrels of typical western money 
> culture.  I throw parties, I've thrown raves, I have a monthly club event- 
> hating on the scene?  No.  Hating on the corporatization of the scene? 
> Sure.
>
> Hit me back when your favorite fancy restaurant starts handing you your 
> filet mignon in a cone of newspaper and tells you it's gonna cost another 
> $100 for a table and a place setting.  It's worse than corruption of a 
> positive thing- it's simply terrible business and customer service.  At 
> this point, all one can do is vote with one's dollar, and that's what I 
> do.  As we speak, there are still plenty of prime places to club in SF 
> that haven't fallen prey to this nonsense.
>
> To each their own, and I'm happy that you're having fun and mean no 
> disrespect.  If you must deal with this in the places you like to go, then 
> more power to you and I commend your positive attitude- but don't try and 
> tell me you think this is a positive trend.  Getting more for your money 
> is never a bad thing.
>
> Remember when you used to find out that the rave you were at had free 
> fruit and water?  Wasn't that a nice feeling?  Would you rather have paid 
> for it?
>
> -positive pedro
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] thread kill -  Vegas Baby Ya!

I am stoked this thread has gone where it has.. great discussion on culture, 
business, and trend.  I know that I do not hold Vegas up as my standard to 
the end-all-be-all of musci and party culture.. and I don't think ANYONE 
here does either.. because many of them came from SF and threw some of the 
biggest massives at Home Base and yes.. they (I was not yet partying)  all 
know eachother and continue to watch the scene evolve, the same us us 
revelors ~ some for the music, some for the culture, some for profit.  Hey - 
it's all part of the game.. like they say.. don't hate the player!

I write for diversity.. I am not here to criticise.. where would my 
experiences lead me if I did.  I would be too critical of this or that, I 
would only hang out in the living rooms of my DJ friends because of course 
they are all bad ass mutha fuckin DJs.. with free music and great vibe.  And 
I do.  But I also want more and less at times.. I want diversity, new crowds 
experience.. good and bad.. no matter what the price at times cuz sometimes 
it's free.. and sometimes it costs a lot more than money.  Pick your 
battles, dig deep.. be engaged wherever you find yourself.

Anyways.. I think that just about wraps up my reports for Vegas.. because 
now the real fun begins for the weekday parties.. the good local shit.  And 
as they say.. what happens in Vegas.. won't be makin it back on SFR :)

I'm all right with a little dig.. no worries.. just trying to share a little 
vibe with ya'll ~ make of it whatever you like.. but now you know a little 
bit more about Ranger.. aka Rock Baby LOL ((-]


SFR: Ranger
San Francisco
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see




From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
Reply-To: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: Nic Werner <nicwerner@gmail.com>
CC: Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update
Date: Mon, 26 Jun 2006 13:12:42 -0700 (PDT)

You're right, it's a great business idea!  I guess I protest more because I 
don't want to see clubs that *don't* extort like this edged out or forced to 
conform by clubs that do this.  Already there're a couple of places I used 
to love that are not worth visiting anymore due to this phenomenon.

The part I didn't touch on is the effect on the clientele this trend has 
had.  I'm not one to make generalizations, but my experience is that (my 
definitition of) people I like to club with don't really love hanging out in 
these places.  That's fine right now, but what if this was de rigeur?  
Clubbing would be permanently changed, and in my opinion, not for the 
better.

-GC

new 'cool-but-not-cool' place.

I agree w/George on all points, but I would have no qualms owning one
of those wack clubs and taking their money - why argue with demand,
idiotic or not? :)

> Hey... I actually totally agree with the
> "hate-on-bottle-service" ideals... BUT... since there
> is no choice here, you have to make the best of it,

>
> You have to look at it this way for us:
> Drinks are $18 a piece.
> Door is $30
> So, door and 3 drinks with no place to chill is about
> $100.
>
> Table service gets you a place to chill, way more than
> you can drink, and costs about the same...
>
> Yeah it sucks, but if you go with a group of solid
> friends, meet new people, and have a good time, it
> works out just fine.
>

> in places like SF... its nitrous to the party... But
> here, people dance on the chairs, the tables, the
> poles, whatver... rather than make everyone sit down,
> people make the best of their rented space....

In-Reply-To: <20060626200510.71669.qmail@web60319.mail.yahoo.com>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

Lol you seem to think this is a new phenomenon or something, nightlife in
general and clubs specifically have often been just as much about
exclusivity as inclusivity.  Bottle service has been around for a loonngggg
time my friend, so has the VIP room, the coke room, the guestlist, etc.

There are places in SF that cater to all tastes and very few venues do
bottle service or enforce a dress code, for people that enjoy that
atmosphere enjoy do your thing I will go do mine, plenty of options around.

A

> -----Original Message-----
> From: georgeC | origami [mailto:newstylesound@yahoo.com]
> Sent: Monday, June 26, 2006 1:05 PM
> To: Eric Spire
> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update
> 
> Figure I'll address both replies at once:
> 
> I'm not hating for the point of hating.  I frankly believe that table and
> bottle service is killing club culture, and I love clubbing, so it kills
> me to see this happen.  Open and shut.  Before this started creeping into
> clubs around here, by and large clubs were places you could go, with or
> without friends, with or without much money.  You could go, see great
> music, meet fun people, spend a little money on drinks or whatever you
> want, sit wherever you want, etc.  Clubs were designed to bring people
> together and foster social interaction.
> 
> Table/bottle service not only serves to cloister folks off in their own
> little worlds.  It also sets up a dichotomy of class where there never was
> one before- those who can afford the luxury box, and those who can't.  The
> social interaction aspect is de-emphasized, as is the music
> appreciation/dancing side of things.  The dancefloors at these places are
> smaller because many folks are just off doing their table thing and the
> sound systems are often terrible.  Some clubs have no seating at all
> besides at the rented tables.  What happened to having a place to take a
> breather after a couple of hours of hard dancing?  Oh yeah, get out the
> wallet.
> 
> The world, IMHO, is bifurcated enough.  Clubs always have stood as social
> blenders and transporters to another world- places to go to FORGET THE
> OUTSIDE WORLD for a little while.  When have-and-have-not segregation
> creeps into the picture, the "corporate" world creeps in with it.  Not
> only must you "dress to impress" (who?), you've got to pony up the scrill
> just to sit down.  Your needs as a consumer are not thought of.   It'd be
> like buying a Mercedes and finding out as the sale closed that the
> driver's seat is an extra grand.
> 
> ---
> 
> "Here are your keys, Mr. Morris, enjoy!"
> 
> "Hey, there's no driver's seat..  Where do I sit?"
> 
> "Sit?  Hmm, on the floor, I suppose, how should I know?"
> 
> "Normally there are things called seats in automobiles- drivers and
> passengers use them to sit in."
> 
> "Oh, you must be speaking about the Premium Posterior Support System!  Its
> padded, adjustable cushions provide exceedingly pleasurable seating for
> the driver who must have only the best.  Also included in this package is
> a seat belt, which can be of great help in keeping one's face out of the
> windshield in an accident!  That'll add one thousand dollars to the
> selling price.  A very good pick, sir!"  Etc etc...
> 
> ---
> 
> Do you honestly think that comfortable places for people to sit and enjoy
> cocktails are something one should have to pay more (past the cover) for?
> The clubs I go to have great seating, great drinks, and great music
> (better than most ultra lounges by a long yard).  The people who dreamed
> this sort of thing up are laughing all the way to the bank, folks.  I hate
> to stick in yet another dramatization, but this is how that conversation
> went:
> 
> ---
> 
> "Yo, Vinnie, times are tough, how are we gonna get things going here?"
> 
> "Shit, I dunno..  Hey, you know all those booths we got that people like
> to sit in with friends?  How about if we put up signs that say 'by
> reservation only', and charge people a couple hundred bones to sit there?"
> 
> "Whoa, the crack must have been fresh this morning, Vinnie- why would
> anybody pay to sit down?"
> 
> "Well, we'll take all the rest of the chairs out, first off- and we'll
> redesign the club and the promo to imply that if you don't got a table,
> you're dirt, and you'd better start saving your pennies.  You know how
> those rich guys love to feel more important than everybody else- they'll
> love a chance at exclusivity in a place where they're usually too unclued
> and uncool to hang out!"
> 
> "Hey now, that's pretty smart- but if they're paying that kind of dosh
> just so sit down, they're not gonna wanna get up all the time.."
> 
> "..so we'll sell em a bottle of liquor we pay $10 for for another couple
> of hundred bucks, and throw in some 'complimentary' juice and soda, too!
> That way the bartenders won't even have to service them!"
> 
> "Shit, you're a genius, pass that crackpipe.."
> 
> ---
> 
> You go to a club with friends, you have some drinks, you are comfortable
> and you have a great time.  Would you have a better time if you paid to
> sit down, or if you had a nice place to sit down that didn't cost money?
> I don't know about you, but when I go out, I go out to mingle, to meet new
> people, to dance, to enjoy my city's culture.  If I want to sit and down a
> bottle with some friends, I'll do it in my living room, at 1/10th the
> cost, where I can choose the music myself and hear my friends talking.
> Call me crazy...
> 
> I create vibe wherever I go, too, Ranger, but I find it easier to have a
> good time when I'm not staring down both barrels of typical western money
> culture.  I throw parties, I've thrown raves, I have a monthly club event-
> hating on the scene?  No.  Hating on the corporatization of the scene?
> Sure.
> 
> Hit me back when your favorite fancy restaurant starts handing you your
> filet mignon in a cone of newspaper and tells you it's gonna cost another
> $100 for a table and a place setting.  It's worse than corruption of a
> positive thing- it's simply terrible business and customer service.  At
> this point, all one can do is vote with one's dollar, and that's what I
> do.  As we speak, there are still plenty of prime places to club in SF
> that haven't fallen prey to this nonsense.
> 
> To each their own, and I'm happy that you're having fun and mean no
> disrespect.  If you must deal with this in the places you like to go, then
> more power to you and I commend your positive attitude- but don't try and
> tell me you think this is a positive trend.  Getting more for your money
> is never a bad thing.
> 
> Remember when you used to find out that the rave you were at had free
> fruit and water?  Wasn't that a nice feeling?  Would you rather have paid
> for it?
> 
> -positive pedro

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

I don't think he thinks this is a new phenomenon, but one that is becoming 
more prevalent, and therefore making clubbing (in general) more on the side 
of "lame" than "cool".

It's just another reminder of the growing class divide...and in a place 
where you're supposed to be having fun and dancing and whatnot, that's a 
shitty place to be reminded of it.

Sheesh.

>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: georgeC | origami [mailto:newstylesound@yahoo.com]
>> Sent: Monday, June 26, 2006 1:05 PM
>> To: Eric Spire
>> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update
>>
>> Figure I'll address both replies at once:
>>
>> I'm not hating for the point of hating.  I frankly believe that table and
>> bottle service is killing club culture, and I love clubbing, so it kills
>> me to see this happen.  Open and shut.  Before this started creeping into
>> clubs around here, by and large clubs were places you could go, with or
>> without friends, with or without much money.  You could go, see great
>> music, meet fun people, spend a little money on drinks or whatever you
>> want, sit wherever you want, etc.  Clubs were designed to bring people
>> together and foster social interaction.
>>
>> Table/bottle service not only serves to cloister folks off in their own
>> little worlds.  It also sets up a dichotomy of class where there never 
>> was
>> one before- those who can afford the luxury box, and those who can't. 
>> The
>> social interaction aspect is de-emphasized, as is the music
>> appreciation/dancing side of things.  The dancefloors at these places are
>> smaller because many folks are just off doing their table thing and the
>> sound systems are often terrible.  Some clubs have no seating at all
>> besides at the rented tables.  What happened to having a place to take a
>> breather after a couple of hours of hard dancing?  Oh yeah, get out the
>> wallet.
>>
>> The world, IMHO, is bifurcated enough.  Clubs always have stood as social
>> blenders and transporters to another world- places to go to FORGET THE
>> OUTSIDE WORLD for a little while.  When have-and-have-not segregation
>> creeps into the picture, the "corporate" world creeps in with it.  Not
>> only must you "dress to impress" (who?), you've got to pony up the scrill
>> just to sit down.  Your needs as a consumer are not thought of.   It'd be
>> like buying a Mercedes and finding out as the sale closed that the
>> driver's seat is an extra grand.
>>
>> ---
>>
>> "Here are your keys, Mr. Morris, enjoy!"
>>
>> "Hey, there's no driver's seat..  Where do I sit?"
>>
>> "Sit?  Hmm, on the floor, I suppose, how should I know?"
>>
>> "Normally there are things called seats in automobiles- drivers and
>> passengers use them to sit in."
>>
>> "Oh, you must be speaking about the Premium Posterior Support System! 
>> Its
>> padded, adjustable cushions provide exceedingly pleasurable seating for
>> the driver who must have only the best.  Also included in this package is
>> a seat belt, which can be of great help in keeping one's face out of the
>> windshield in an accident!  That'll add one thousand dollars to the
>> selling price.  A very good pick, sir!"  Etc etc...
>>
>> ---
>>
>> Do you honestly think that comfortable places for people to sit and enjoy
>> cocktails are something one should have to pay more (past the cover) for?
>> The clubs I go to have great seating, great drinks, and great music
>> (better than most ultra lounges by a long yard).  The people who dreamed
>> this sort of thing up are laughing all the way to the bank, folks.  I 
>> hate
>> to stick in yet another dramatization, but this is how that conversation
>> went:
>>
>> ---
>>
>> "Yo, Vinnie, times are tough, how are we gonna get things going here?"
>>
>> "Shit, I dunno..  Hey, you know all those booths we got that people like
>> to sit in with friends?  How about if we put up signs that say 'by
>> reservation only', and charge people a couple hundred bones to sit 
>> there?"
>>
>> "Whoa, the crack must have been fresh this morning, Vinnie- why would
>> anybody pay to sit down?"
>>
>> "Well, we'll take all the rest of the chairs out, first off- and we'll
>> redesign the club and the promo to imply that if you don't got a table,
>> you're dirt, and you'd better start saving your pennies.  You know how
>> those rich guys love to feel more important than everybody else- they'll
>> love a chance at exclusivity in a place where they're usually too unclued
>> and uncool to hang out!"
>>
>> "Hey now, that's pretty smart- but if they're paying that kind of dosh
>> just so sit down, they're not gonna wanna get up all the time.."
>>
>> "..so we'll sell em a bottle of liquor we pay $10 for for another couple
>> of hundred bucks, and throw in some 'complimentary' juice and soda, too!
>> That way the bartenders won't even have to service them!"
>>
>> "Shit, you're a genius, pass that crackpipe.."
>>
>> ---
>>
>> You go to a club with friends, you have some drinks, you are comfortable
>> and you have a great time.  Would you have a better time if you paid to
>> sit down, or if you had a nice place to sit down that didn't cost money?
>> I don't know about you, but when I go out, I go out to mingle, to meet 
>> new
>> people, to dance, to enjoy my city's culture.  If I want to sit and down 
>> a
>> bottle with some friends, I'll do it in my living room, at 1/10th the
>> cost, where I can choose the music myself and hear my friends talking.
>> Call me crazy...
>>
>> I create vibe wherever I go, too, Ranger, but I find it easier to have a
>> good time when I'm not staring down both barrels of typical western money
>> culture.  I throw parties, I've thrown raves, I have a monthly club 
>> event-
>> hating on the scene?  No.  Hating on the corporatization of the scene?
>> Sure.
>>
>> Hit me back when your favorite fancy restaurant starts handing you your
>> filet mignon in a cone of newspaper and tells you it's gonna cost another
>> $100 for a table and a place setting.  It's worse than corruption of a
>> positive thing- it's simply terrible business and customer service.  At
>> this point, all one can do is vote with one's dollar, and that's what I
>> do.  As we speak, there are still plenty of prime places to club in SF
>> that haven't fallen prey to this nonsense.
>>
>> To each their own, and I'm happy that you're having fun and mean no
>> disrespect.  If you must deal with this in the places you like to go, 
>> then

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

> Does Vegas no longer do the "free liquor while you gamble" thing?
>

Yes, they do, it's just not consistent.

I guess if you are on a uber budget you can loiter around the slots, 
pretend to gamble and get free drinks, but sometimes the cocktail 
waitresses just dissappear and you're stuck waiting forever. Plus the free 
courtesy drink usually suck.

You can usually get much better free drink service at say, a $25 blackjack 
table. But that only works if you're winning, or at least breaking even.

I like the locals dive bar approach.

I remember going to a rave (not club) in Vegas that Siphon had a gig at, 
can't remember where, but they had this dive bar attached to it. Nobody 
except us went in because they either didn't know about it, or they 
weren't 21 (it was kindaofa kiddie-rave)

Long story short, the bartender rigs the pool table so we can play for 
free, charges us like $2-3 for top shelf, and gives us a bunch of free 
rounds. Four of us drank *all night* for less than $60.

I've paid $60 for a round of 3 drinks at the Bellagio.

-terry

On Mon, 26 Jun 2006, Marc(O) wrote:

> charged for cocktails. We basically just did that the whole time, and when we 
> were good and wasted, THEN we went out to the clubs...hehe.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

Yea...I do remember some casino's being more inconsistant about the free 
drinks. And thus my methodology of going to the Fremont street area (or "old 
Vegas") and hitting the Golden Nugget or one of those old casinos - they 
tend to pour a little more heavy and bring drinks more frequently - plus 
they let you get multiple coktails sometimes...

I dunno, like I said, I brought $50 with me, and even though a friend paid 
for my meals, that $50 got me slots gambling and many a free cocktail. 
Anyone who knows me knows I drink a lot, and I was fairly trashed the entire 
two and half days...so something was working in my favor, lol.

> I like the locals dive bar approach.
>
> I remember going to a rave (not club) in Vegas that Siphon had a gig at, 
> can't remember where, but they had this dive bar attached to it. Nobody 
> except us went in because they either didn't know about it, or they 
> weren't 21 (it was kindaofa kiddie-rave)
>
> Long story short, the bartender rigs the pool table so we can play for 
> free, charges us like $2-3 for top shelf, and gives us a bunch of free 
> rounds. Four of us drank *all night* for less than $60.
>
> I've paid $60 for a round of 3 drinks at the Bellagio.
>
> -terry
>
> On Mon, 26 Jun 2006, Marc(O) wrote:
>
>> Does Vegas no longer do the "free liquor while you gamble" thing?
>>

Message-ID: <20060626223606.82453.qmail@web60324.mail.yahoo.com>

From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
Reply-To: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: Andrew Phelan <mailinglists@djandrewphelan.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Table/Bottle service  Was: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

I know it's not new, but it's certainly growing in popularity, and I think that sucks.  Good clubbing, to me, is still about inclusivity.  A good club is just a couple of steps away from a good underground party, ideally- with better infrastructure and legitimacy.  All of these see-and-be-seen "services" are the work of entrepreneurs and marketing people that strive to reap the financial benefits of social pressures and class divisions.  Bottom-feeding behavior of the lowest level, and unfortunately, very American.

So yeah, that attitude and its trappings may be age-old, but that doesn't mean they belong here.  Just 5 years ago I could count the number of places in SF that trifled with this foolishness on one hand, and none of them were considered real nightspots- they were considered caches for the rich.  

But yeah, hey, to each their own...  ..until all of my favorite clubs become marina-chick/fidi-guy clutches, and then, by gum, it's gonna be WAR.  (or time to move)  ;)

-g



----- Original Message ----
From: Andrew Phelan <mailinglists@djandrewphelan.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, June 26, 2006 2:33:54 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

Lol you seem to think this is a new phenomenon or something, nightlife in
general and clubs specifically have often been just as much about
exclusivity as inclusivity.  Bottle service has been around for a loonngggg
time my friend, so has the VIP room, the coke room, the guestlist, etc.

There are places in SF that cater to all tastes and very few venues do
bottle service or enforce a dress code, for people that enjoy that
atmosphere enjoy do your thing I will go do mine, plenty of options around.

A

> -----Original Message-----
> From: georgeC | origami [mailto:newstylesound@yahoo.com]
> Sent: Monday, June 26, 2006 1:05 PM
> To: Eric Spire
> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update
> 
> Figure I'll address both replies at once:
> 
> I'm not hating for the point of hating.  I frankly believe that table and
> bottle service is killing club culture, and I love clubbing, so it kills
> me to see this happen.  Open and shut.  Before this started creeping into
> clubs around here, by and large clubs were places you could go, with or
> without friends, with or without much money.  You could go, see great
> music, meet fun people, spend a little money on drinks or whatever you
> want, sit wherever you want, etc.  Clubs were designed to bring people
> together and foster social interaction.
> 
> Table/bottle service not only serves to cloister folks off in their own
> little worlds.  It also sets up a dichotomy of class where there never was
> one before- those who can afford the luxury box, and those who can't.  The
> social interaction aspect is de-emphasized, as is the music
> appreciation/dancing side of things.  The dancefloors at these places are
> smaller because many folks are just off doing their table thing and the
> sound systems are often terrible.  Some clubs have no seating at all
> besides at the rented tables.  What happened to having a place to take a
> breather after a couple of hours of hard dancing?  Oh yeah, get out the
> wallet.
> 
> The world, IMHO, is bifurcated enough.  Clubs always have stood as social
> blenders and transporters to another world- places to go to FORGET THE
> OUTSIDE WORLD for a little while.  When have-and-have-not segregation
> creeps into the picture, the "corporate" world creeps in with it.  Not
> only must you "dress to impress" (who?), you've got to pony up the scrill
> just to sit down.  Your needs as a consumer are not thought of.   It'd be
> like buying a Mercedes and finding out as the sale closed that the
> driver's seat is an extra grand.
> 
> ---
> 
> "Here are your keys, Mr. Morris, enjoy!"
> 
> "Hey, there's no driver's seat..  Where do I sit?"
> 
> "Sit?  Hmm, on the floor, I suppose, how should I know?"
> 
> "Normally there are things called seats in automobiles- drivers and
> passengers use them to sit in."
> 
> "Oh, you must be speaking about the Premium Posterior Support System!  Its
> padded, adjustable cushions provide exceedingly pleasurable seating for
> the driver who must have only the best.  Also included in this package is
> a seat belt, which can be of great help in keeping one's face out of the
> windshield in an accident!  That'll add one thousand dollars to the
> selling price.  A very good pick, sir!"  Etc etc...
> 
> ---
> 
> Do you honestly think that comfortable places for people to sit and enjoy
> cocktails are something one should have to pay more (past the cover) for?
> The clubs I go to have great seating, great drinks, and great music
> (better than most ultra lounges by a long yard).  The people who dreamed
> this sort of thing up are laughing all the way to the bank, folks.  I hate
> to stick in yet another dramatization, but this is how that conversation
> went:
> 
> ---
> 
> "Yo, Vinnie, times are tough, how are we gonna get things going here?"
> 
> "Shit, I dunno..  Hey, you know all those booths we got that people like
> to sit in with friends?  How about if we put up signs that say 'by
> reservation only', and charge people a couple hundred bones to sit there?"
> 
> "Whoa, the crack must have been fresh this morning, Vinnie- why would
> anybody pay to sit down?"
> 
> "Well, we'll take all the rest of the chairs out, first off- and we'll
> redesign the club and the promo to imply that if you don't got a table,
> you're dirt, and you'd better start saving your pennies.  You know how
> those rich guys love to feel more important than everybody else- they'll
> love a chance at exclusivity in a place where they're usually too unclued
> and uncool to hang out!"
> 
> "Hey now, that's pretty smart- but if they're paying that kind of dosh
> just so sit down, they're not gonna wanna get up all the time.."
> 
> "..so we'll sell em a bottle of liquor we pay $10 for for another couple
> of hundred bucks, and throw in some 'complimentary' juice and soda, too!
> That way the bartenders won't even have to service them!"
> 
> "Shit, you're a genius, pass that crackpipe.."
> 
> ---
> 
> You go to a club with friends, you have some drinks, you are comfortable
> and you have a great time.  Would you have a better time if you paid to
> sit down, or if you had a nice place to sit down that didn't cost money?
> I don't know about you, but when I go out, I go out to mingle, to meet new
> people, to dance, to enjoy my city's culture.  If I want to sit and down a
> bottle with some friends, I'll do it in my living room, at 1/10th the
> cost, where I can choose the music myself and hear my friends talking.
> Call me crazy...
> 
> I create vibe wherever I go, too, Ranger, but I find it easier to have a
> good time when I'm not staring down both barrels of typical western money
> culture.  I throw parties, I've thrown raves, I have a monthly club event-
> hating on the scene?  No.  Hating on the corporatization of the scene?
> Sure.
> 
> Hit me back when your favorite fancy restaurant starts handing you your
> filet mignon in a cone of newspaper and tells you it's gonna cost another
> $100 for a table and a place setting.  It's worse than corruption of a
> positive thing- it's simply terrible business and customer service.  At
> this point, all one can do is vote with one's dollar, and that's what I
> do.  As we speak, there are still plenty of prime places to club in SF
> that haven't fallen prey to this nonsense.
> 
> To each their own, and I'm happy that you're having fun and mean no
> disrespect.  If you must deal with this in the places you like to go, then
> more power to you and I commend your positive attitude- but don't try and
> tell me you think this is a positive trend.  Getting more for your money
> is never a bad thing.
> 
> Remember when you used to find out that the rave you were at had free
> fruit and water?  Wasn't that a nice feeling?  Would you rather have paid
> for it?
> 
> -positive pedro
> 
>

Here's another gross thing about bottle service...

Since they require you to buy a bottle for evry 4
people, there is almost no chnace of finishing the
liquor... So what do they do? They "marry" the
leftovers into their bar stock , thus selling the
liquor twice.

--- georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:

> I know it's not new, but it's certainly growing in
> popularity, and I think that sucks.  Good clubbing,
> to me, is still about inclusivity.  A good club is
> just a couple of steps away from a good underground
> party, ideally- with better infrastructure and
> legitimacy.  All of these see-and-be-seen "services"
> are the work of entrepreneurs and marketing people
> that strive to reap the financial benefits of social
> pressures and class divisions.  Bottom-feeding
> behavior of the lowest level, and unfortunately,
> very American.
> 
> So yeah, that attitude and its trappings may be
> age-old, but that doesn't mean they belong here. 
> Just 5 years ago I could count the number of places
> in SF that trifled with this foolishness on one
> hand, and none of them were considered real
> nightspots- they were considered caches for the
> rich.  
> 
> But yeah, hey, to each their own...  ..until all of
> my favorite clubs become marina-chick/fidi-guy
> clutches, and then, by gum, it's gonna be WAR.  (or
> time to move)  ;)
> 
> -g

>> in SF that trifled with this foolishness on one
>> hand, and none of them were considered real
>> nightspots- they were considered caches for the
>> rich.

>> my favorite clubs become marina-chick/fidi-guy
>> clutches, and then, by gum, it's gonna be WAR.  (or
>> time to move)  ;)

On Jun 26, 2006, at 3:36 PM, georgeC | origami wrote:

> I know it's not new, but it's certainly growing in popularity, and  
> I think that sucks.  Good clubbing, to me, is still about  
> inclusivity.  A good club is just a couple of steps away from a  
> good underground party, ideally- with better infrastructure and  
> legitimacy.  All of these see-and-be-seen "services" are the work  
> of entrepreneurs and marketing people that strive to reap the  
> financial benefits of social pressures and class divisions.  Bottom- 
> feeding behavior of the lowest level, and unfortunately, very  
> American.
>
> So yeah, that attitude and its trappings may be age-old, but that  
> doesn't mean they belong here.  Just 5 years ago I could count the  
> number of places in SF that trifled with this foolishness on one  
> hand, and none of them were considered real nightspots- they were  
> considered caches for the rich.
>
> But yeah, hey, to each their own...  ..until all of my favorite  
> clubs become marina-chick/fidi-guy clutches, and then, by gum, it's  
> gonna be WAR.  (or time to move)  ;)
>
> -g
>

I would be very interested in studying the demographics of dress-shoe  
clubs in both Vegas and San Francisco.  The former would be heavily  
tourist oriented I would think and therefore Vegas clubs would  
attract those who spend heavily for a few days...not locals who work  
in the tourist business. Where do the locals party?  Do bar tenders,  
etc., accumulate enough wealth to spend hundreds of discretionary  
dollars each weekend in clubs?

San Francisco, IMHO, is becoming more like Vegas.  With the middle  
class disappearing all over the Bay SF entertainment will focus more  
on the discretionary dollars of tourists than those who smoke some  
weed and drink free water all night.

Raves began here when, amongst other irritations, the communal dance  
folks got tired of the clubs.  Raves ended when those involved saw  
opportunities to make bucks...like the clubs.  My partner collected  
boxes of old fliers from late eighties early nineties SF underground  
gay and mixed parties we used to attend.  All of them were hand  
written and run off on color papers.  Some were stickers one would  
paste on one's black motorcycle jacket:)  Then came the late  
nineties.  Four color fliers.  BIG.



Apollo



apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Message-ID: <20060627014917.69127.qmail@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 26 Jun 2006 18:49:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>
To: Amadu78 <amadu78@hotmail.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY107-DAV162580015EEC970A868129BC7E0@phx.gbl>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Table/Bottle service  

Actually, some places will let you walk with the
bottle if it's capped, others will hold it for the
next night, but all of them don't tell you this and
certainly make no effort to let you know...

My biggest thing about the bottle service requirement
is this:
One bottle per four people guarantees that everyone is
drunk. Forcing you to order enough liquor guarantees
that there is no sober driver. They are responsible
for cutting you off if you've had to much... Thus the
paradox of requiring you to order enough to get drunk,
while legally having to cut you off when you've had
too much.

Personally, I would rather have to pay a "table fee"
and get bottles for a reasonable price, rather than
have the table price built into the bottles. On big
weekends, like fight nights, nascar, Car shows, etc...
they bump the bottle requirment to a minimum of 3
bottles, PERIOD, regardless of how many people are
with you.

Luckily, my friends and I know someone in charge at
nearly every establishment, and because liquor reps
are constantly pushing their new thing, we usually get
a buy 1 get one comped deal, which makes it about
$400-500 for a group of 8 or so... which really aint
that bad at the end of the night.

Like I said though, this model is moving everytwhere.
When I moved here, I couldn't believe how lame the
clubs were. Music wise, most still are. I thought the
SF style would come here sooner or llater, but it
seems the reverse is happening, including the shitty
music format.

It's one of those things that sucks, but is coming no
matter weather you want it or not...Kinda like trance
hitting SF in the late 90's... It was horrible, we all
imagined that it would never take over the groovy
house vibe in SF... but it certainly did.

E

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Table/Bottle service  Was: Re: [sfraves] Vegas Baby Ya! - Update

About 5-7 years ago my wife and I went to a small after hours place off the strip called 1030.  The only people there besides us were locals from the service industry getting off the late shift.  I think there was a $5 cover, but the drinks were cheap and there was no bottle service that I saw.  Just funky SF style house, smiling, and dancing...

I guess that place is gone now...I think the Boston Grill took over that space.  But I think other places like this must still exist.  Maybe not...

Peace,

Peter

clubs in both Vegas and San Francisco.  The former would be heavily  
tourist oriented I would think and therefore Vegas clubs would  
attract those who spend heavily for a few days...not locals who work  
in the tourist business. Where do the locals party?  Do bar tenders,  
etc., accumulate enough wealth to spend hundreds of discretionary  
dollars each weekend in clubs?

class disappearing all over the Bay SF entertainment will focus more  
on the discretionary dollars of tourists than those who smoke some  
weed and drink free water all night.
